Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT MANAGEMENT COMPETENCE OF THE PATHFINDER FUND (PF) AS OF OCTOBER 1978 BASED ON EVALUATION TEAM MEETINGS WITH MEMBERS AND REVIEW OF PF SUPPORTED PROJECTS. PF WORLD- WIDE PROGRAMS DURING THE PERIOD 1976-78 HAVE BEEN ADMINISTERED EFFECTIVELY AND HAVE MET ASSIGNED OBJECTIVES IN SPITE OF THE HIGH TURNOVER OF TOP PERSONNEL DURING THE PERIOD 1973-78. AS A RESULT OF THE "NEW PATHS COMMITTEE REPORT" OF 1975, A POLICY DIVISION ND WOMEN'S PROGRAM DIVISION WERE ADDED TO  THE PROGRAM OF FERTILITY SERVICES. THE DEFINITION OF ROLES BETWEEN THESE NEW DIVISIONS IS UNCLEAR, BUT THE QUALITY OF THE DIVISIONS IS GOOD. IN THE AREA OF PROJECT DEVELOPMENT, THE PF APPROACH OF ALLOWING RECIPIENTS TO PARTICIPATE IN PROJECT DESIGN IS FEASIBLE. EVALUATORS RECOMMEND THAT PF REVIEW WITH AID ITS GOALS REGARDING WOMEN'S PROGRAMS, THAT IT UPDATE ITS KNOWLEDGE OF FAMILY PLANNING STRATEGIES, AND THAT IT GAIN THE CAPABILITY TO DEVELOP LONGER-TERM PROJECTS. PROJECT REVIEW ACTIVITIES ARE LARGELY QUANTITATIVE; QUALITATIVE, ON-SITE EVALUATORS ARE SPORADIC AND VARIABLE BOTH IN CONTENT AN D INTENSITY. THE RECOMMENDATION IS THAT PF UPGRADE BOTH ITS BOSTON AND FIELD OFFICES TO DO QUALITATIVE EVALUATION AND THAT IT INSTITUTIONALIZE SUCH WORK, WHILE TAKING CARE TO AVOID INJECTING EXCESSIVE DATA COLLECTIONS AND ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES THAT MAY INTERFERE WITH SERVICE DELIVERY. THE SKILLS OF REGIONAL AND COUNTRY REPRESENTATIVES VARY WIDELY ALTHOUGH ALL HAVE SPECIAL SKILLS IN ONE OR ANOTHER AREA. MOST PF PROJECTS ARE INNOVATIVE AND WELL DELIVERED. REPORTING AND RECORDING OF PROJECT RESULTS ARE WELL DONE AND FOLLOW DESIGN AND INSTRUCTIONS. HOWEVER, PATHFINDER SHOULD AUTHORIZE SOME OF THEIR FIELD REPRESENTATIVES TO ARRANGE TELEX SERVICES FOR COMMUNICATIONS WITH BOSTON.

Abstract: EVALUATES ASIAN PROJECT ACTIVITIES OF THE PATHFINDER FUND (PF) AS OF 2/27/79 BASED ON FIELD VISITS. PF SUPPORTED PROJECTS IN BANGLADESH ARE THOUGHT OUT AND EFFECTIVELY ADMINISTERED, AND ENHANCE POPULATION AND FAMILY PLANNING EFFORTS. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT AID SHOULD SUPPORT ASIAN PROJECTS FOR TWO TO FOUR MORE YEARS, AND PF AND THE GOVERNMENT OF BANGLADESH SHOULD DEVELOP ALTERNATIVE SOURCES OF FINANCIAL SUPPORT. PF SHOULD ALSO TRY TO WORK WITH PVO'S ACTIVE IN POPULATION AND FAMILY PLANNING, ESPECIALLY IN NON-RURAL COMMUNITIES OUTSIDE DACCA, AND CONTINUE TO DEVELOP PROJECTS WITH RELEVANT ELEMENTS OF THE PRIVATE SECTOR, E.G., RAILWAY WORKERS. ALSO, WOMEN SHOULD BE GIVEN ROLES IN PVO FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAMS. THE FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAM IN INDONESIA IS RIGOROUS, AND PF'S EMPHASIS ON SUPPORT FOR SPECIALIZED SERVICE PROGRAMS, SUCH AS THE TRAINING OF PHYSICIANS IN STERILIZATION TECHNIQUES, IS THE CORRECT ONE. THE STERILIZATION CENTERS PLAY A KEY ROLE IN TRAINING AND ARE BELLWETHERS FOR OTHER ELEMENTS OF THE STERILIZATION SERVICE DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT PF EFFORTS TO WORK WITH RELIGIOUS GROUPS SUCH AS MOHAMMADIYAH AND THAT THE ROLE PLAYED BY RELIGIOUS LEADERS IN THE DECISION-MAKING PROCESS IN THE VILLAGES SHOULD BE SUPPORTED. IT IS HOPED THAT PF WILL BE ABLE TO ASISST THE ZPG GROOP TO DEVELOP A LONG-TERM SOURCE OF IN-COUNTRY SUPPORT. THIS MAY REQUIRE THAT PF PROVIDE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO SELECTED ZPG PROJECTS OVER THE NEXT TWO OR THREE YEARS. PF PROJECTS IN THAILAND ARE MOVING THAT COUNTRY CLOSER TO HAVING A BODY OF NON-PROFESSIONALS ABLE TO PARTICIPATE IN FAMILY PLANNING SERVICE DELIVERY. PF HAS LEFT A LEGACY OF CONTINUING INTEREST IN BROADENING THE TECHNICAL SKILLS OF PARAMEDICAL PERSONNEL. GIVEN THE MATURITY OF THE THAILAND FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAM, THE STRONG ROYAL THAI GOVERNMENT FINANCIAL AND POLICY SUPPORT, AND BROAD SUPPORT FROM BILATERAL, INTERNATIONAL, AND VOLUNTARY AGENCIES, PF DOES NOT HAVE A LARGE FUTURE ROLE IN THAILAND.

Abstract: EVALUATES FROM 7/76 TO 4/79 OPG (AID-AFR-G-1249) TO SAVE THE CHILDREN FEDERATION (SCF) FOR DORI INTEGRATED RURAL DEVELOPMENT PROJ IN UPPER VOLTA (UV), INTENDED TO CREATE COMMUNITY-BASED INTEGRATED RURAL DEVEL PROJS IN 4 UV VILLAGES. EVALUATION, DONE BY SCF, IS BASED ON REVIEW OF PROJ DOCUMENTS, INTERVIEWS WITH PROJ GROUPS, OBSERVATION OF VILLAGE PROJS. PROJ IMPLEMENTATION HAS BEEN REAL BUT SLOW DUE TO LACK OF QUALIFIED IN-COUNTRY STAFF & FATALISTIC ATTITUDES OF VILLAGERS. VILLAGE OF BAFELE DID NOT PARTICIPATE DUE TO LACK OF HANDOUTS & WILL BE RECANVASSED IN 1979. MAJOR SCF PROBLEM HAS BEEN LACK OF STAFF. TRAINING, ESP OF FIELD COORDINATORS & THEREBY OF VILLAGERS, HAS BEEN SLOW AND MORE STAFF TRAINING IS NEEDED. ADMINISTRATIVE NETWORK FOR PROJ IMPLEMENTATION IS IN PLACE, WITH FIELD OFFICE & CENTRAL SUPPORTING OFFICE ESTABLISHED & STAFFED, AND EFFECTIVE CONTACT HAS BEEN MADE WITH NATIONAL & INTERNATIONAL SUPPORT GROUPS. INSTITUTIONALIZATION, HOWEVER, HAS JUST BEGUN & EXPATRIATE STAFF WILL BE NEEDED UNTIL 1986. TRAINING OF VILLAGE LEADERS HAS ALSO BEEN SLOW. TWENTY ONE OF TARGETED 24 VILL COMMITTEES HAVE BEEN FORMED & HAVE INITIATED 28 OF 40 TARGETED SELF-HELP PROJS, BUT LOSS OF BASELINE DATA SURVEY MAKES ADEQUATE EVALUATION IMPOSSIBLE. SIX OF 8 TARGETED VILL COMMITTEES TO ENSURE INSTITUTIONALIZATION HAVE BEEN FORMED & 8 MORE ARE PLANNED, BUT THEIR ABILITY TO OPERATE AUTONOMOUSLY IS MINIMAL. GOVT OF UPPER VOLTA (GOUV) IS COMMITTED TO PROJ BUT LACKS ADEQUATE PLANNING CAPABILITY. COMMUNITY SUPPORT WORKERS HAVE NOT YET BEEN TRAINED. ON REGIONAL LEVEL, SCF/GOUV PLANNING SESSIONS HAVE BEEN HELD & SCF HAS PRODUCED 16 REGIONAL PROJ PLANS, BUT TRAINING WORKSHOPS FOR GOUV PERSONNEL HAVE NOT TAKEN PALCE. IN FUTURE, INTER-VILLAGE COORDINATION WILL BE DONE BY MEETINGS BETWEEN VILLAGERS AND GOUV PERSONNEL. PROJ HAS TAUGHT NECESSITY OF ADEQUATE IN-COUNTRY STAFF FOR VILLAGE PROJECTS. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT PRESENT ACCOUNTANT BE REPLACED BY ONE WITH ADEQUATE ACCOUNTING & LANGUAGE SKILLS AND THAT NEW BASELINE SURVEY BE DONE. ATTACHED ARE 4 APPENDICES, MOSTLY IN FRENCH, ON PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND SUBPROJECTS.

Abstract: EVALUATES AFRICA AND MIDDLE EAST PROJECT ACTIVITIES OF THE PATHFINDER FUND (PF) AS OF 2/27/79 BASED ON FIELD VISITS. IN EGYPT, PF IS DEVELOPING A CADRE OF MEDICAL PRACTITIONERS QUALIFIED TO PROVIDE STERILIZATION SERVICES. THIS WILL BE THE BASE FOR BROADENING THE AVAILABILITY OF SUCH SERVICES. THE DEVELOPMENT OF WELL EQUIPPED, STAFFED, AND OPERATED CLINICS FOR PROVISION OF STERILIZATION SERVICES IS EXPECTED TO LEAD TOBROADER ACCEPTANCE OF STERILIZATION. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT PF CONTINUE ITS ROLE OF PROVIDING LOW PROFILE SUPPORT TO TRAINING AND PROVISION OF SERVICES THROUGH CLINICS. THAT WILL HELP PF TO UTILIZE ITS RESOURCES MOST EFFECTIVELY. ALTHOUGH PF HAS BEEN ACTIVE IN SENEGAL SINCE 1973, THERE IS LITTLE TO SHOW FOR THE EFFORT. Abstract: EVALUATES RESEARCH COMPONENT OF PROJECT TO ENHANCE THE RESEARCH, TEACHING, AND EXTENSION CAPABILITIES OF THE FACULTY OF AGRICULTURE OF THE UNIVERSITY OF JORDAN. EVALUATION WAS CONDUCTED BY AN OUTSIDE EXPERT AT THE REQUEST OF THE FACULTY DEAN AND WAS BASED ON FACULTY INTERVIEWS, REVIEW OF ANNUAL REPORTS, AND VISITS TO RESEARCH SITES AND FACILITIES. SOILS AND IRRIGATION DEPARTMENT IS TO BE COMMENDED FOR THE PERTINENCE OF ITS PROGRAM TO CURRENT PROBLEMS; THE QUALITY OF ITS WORK, ESPECIALLY IN SOIL FERTILITY AND CHARACTERIZATION, SOIL MOISTURE CONSERVATION, AND IRRIGATION; AND FOR ITS ADHERENCE TO PROJECT PROPOSAL POLICY. THE PLANT PROTECTION AND PRODUCTION PROGRAM IS ALSO TO BE COMMENDED FOR THE PERTINENCE OF ITS PROGRAM AND FOR ITS TEAM APPROACH. SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE IN WHEAT AND BARLEY RESEARCH. HORTICULTURAL RESEARCH IS JUST BEGINNING. THOUGH SOMEWHAT HAMPERED BY A LACK OF FACILITIES, IT IS PROGRESSING WELL. VALUABLE VEGETABLE CROP RESEARCH IS BEING CARRIED OUT IN COOPERATION WITH IRRIGATION RESEARCH, AND GOOD WORK IS BEING DONE IN FARM MACHINERY, ENTOMOLOGY, AND VARIOUS PEST PROBLEMS. PLANNING IS UNDERWAY FOR RESEARCH IN PESTICIDE RESISTANCE. DUE TO STAFF LIMITATIONS, THE ANIMAL PRODUCTION AND PROTECTION DEPARTMENT HAS CARRIED OUT ONLY LIMITED (BUT GOOD) RESEARCH IN ANIMAL PRODUCTION, NUTRITION, AND FOOD SCIENCE. THE 2 MEMBERS OF THE AGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS AND EXTENSION DEPARTMENT HAVE ALSO DONE GOOD WORK IN VEGETABLE PRODUCTION; OWNER-TENANT RELATIONS UNDER NEW TECHNOLOGY; COST AND RETURN OF NEW TECHNIQUES; DAIRY PRODUCTION; MECHANIZED AGRICULTURE, AND THE ECONOMIC IMPACT OF NEW TECHNOLOGY FOR WHEAT PRODUCTION. THE PRINCIPAL DEFICIENCY IN THE SYSTEM AS A WHOLE HAS BEEN IN REPORTING. REPORTS OFTEN LACK A CLEAR RELATION TO THE WORK BEING DONE OR ARE TOO UNWIELDY FOR USE BY PROJECT ADMINISTRATORS. A UNIFORM FORMAT FOR REPORTS IS THEREFORE RECOMMENDED, AS WELL AS A SET OF GUIDELINES TO ASSIST RESEARCHERS IN PREPARING THEIR REPORTS. EVALUATION IS INCLUDED (PP 30-39) IN FINAL EVALUATION REPORT OF PROJECT (PD-AAC-387-A1).

Abstract: CONSULTANT REPORTS ON HIS TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ACTIVITIES DURING THE PERIOD 10/07/76 - 8/06/79 IN A PROJECT TO IMPROVE RURAL HEALTH IN MONTERO,BOLIVIA. THE CONSULTANT WAS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE RESEARCH AND EVALUATION ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT. DURING THIS PERIOD, 13 MAJOR STUDIES WERE DESIGNED AND INITIATED BY THE CONSULTANT. AS A RESULT OF THESE ACTIVITIES,APPROXIMATELY 95 PEOPLE RECEIVED TRAINING AND SUPERVISED PRACTICE IN ONE OR MORE ASPECTS OF THE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES. HOWEVER,MUCH REMAINED UNFINISHED. THE LACK OF A CLEAR AND COMPREHENSIVE DEFINITION OF INFORMATION NEEDS AND THE INABILITY TO FIND A SUITABLE COUNTERPART ADVERSELY AFFECTED THE PROGRAM. IN ALL, THE ADVISOR PREPARED AND DISTRIBUTED 26 REPORTS AND DOCUMENTS INCLUDING BASIC WORKING DOCUMENTS AND FINAL REPORTS FOR THREE SPECIFIC STUDIES -- "PREVALENCE OF MALNUTRITION IN PRESCHOOL CHILDREN IN 39 COMMUNITIES IN THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF SANTA CRUZ" (7/77),"ANALYSIS OF COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION" (9/78),AND "PERSONNEL UTILIZATION AND ATTITUDES -- AN EVALUATIVE ANALYSIS OF THE SYSTEM" (7/79). A WIDE VARIETY OF INFORMATION WAS COLLECTED ON 72 RURAL COMMUNITIES BY AUXILIARY NURSES,RURAL TEACHERS,AND MEMBERS OF THE DISTRICT OUTREACH TEAM. OTHER ACTIVITIES INCLUDED MAPPING OF COMMUNITIES AND THE METRO AREA,A CENSUS OF POPULATION AND HOUSING,A RURAL HEALTH HOUSEHOLD SURVEY,A LONGITUDINAL MORBIDITY STUDY,A NUTRITIONAL SURVEY OF PRESCHOOL CHILDREN,AND STUDIES OF REGIONAL INSTITUTIONS. THE AUTHOR CONCLUDES THAT ONLY A PORTION OF THE ORIGINALLY PLANNED RESEARCH ACTIVITIES MERITED PRIORITY. FORTUNATELY IN PRACTICE,BROAD FLEXIBILITY WAS PERMITTED IN CONCEPTUALIZING AND MODIFYING THE ORIGINAL RESEARCH PROGRAM--BUT AT CONSIDERABLE COST IN TERMS OF TIME AND ENERGY. THE AUTHOR'S PRIMARY RECOMMENDATION IS THAT ONE OF THE FIRST ACTIVITIES IN EXTENDING RURAL HEALTH SERVICES ON A NATIONAL SCALE SHOULD BE THE DESIGN OF A COMPREHENSIVE EVALUATION SYSTEM.

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT TO PROMOTE RURAL DEVELOPMENT IN THREE DISTRICTS OF NIGER'S DEPARTMENT OF NIAMEY. THE FOUR-MAN EVALUATION TEAM CONDUCTED INTERVIEWS WITH BENEFICIARIES AND LOCAL ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICIALS IN THE THREE PARTICIPATING DISTRICTS. IN ADDITION, MEETINGS WERE HELD IN THE CAPITAL WITH OFFICIALS FROM RELEVANT GOVERNMENT AGENCIES. PROJECT CONSISTED OF 10 PROGRAMS, EACH IMPLEMENTED BY A DIFFERENT GOVERNMENT AGENCY. THESE INCLUDED: PLUVIAL AGRICULTURE (SERVICE AGRICOLE), CREDIT AND COOPERATIVE (UNCC), SOIL CONSERVATION/FORESTRY (EAUX ET FORET), LIVESTOCK (SERVICE DE L'ELEVAGE), LITERACY (SERVICE DE L'ALPHABETISATION), RADIO-CLUB (ASSOCIATION NATIONALE DES RADIO-CLUBS, SMALL IRRIGATION (GENIE RURAL), STUDIES PROGRAM (PROJECT MANAGEMENT UNIT), PROJECT MANAGEMENT UNIT (COTEDEP/PROJECT PERSONNEL), COMPREHENSIVE AREA PLANNING (PROJECT MANAGEMENT UNIT). IN SLIGHTLY OVER ONE YEAR OF IMPLEMENTATION, OVER ONE-HALF OF THE TARGETTED OBJECTIVES WERE ACHIEVED. THE EVALUATION TEAM REACHED 4 GENERAL CONCLUSIONS ABOUT THE PROJECT: (1) A NUMBER OF THE PROJECT COMPONENTS DID NOT UNDERGO ADEQUATE TECHNICAL AND ECONOMIC TESTING; (2) MANY OF THE COMPONENTS SEEMED TO REPRESENT A "SHOPPING LIST" OF GOVERNMENT AGENCY DEMANDS RATHER THAN ACTIVITIES ESSENTIAL TO RURAL DEVELOPMENT; (3) COORDINATING THE ACTIVITIES AMONG THE MANY PARTICIPATING GOVERNMENT AGENCIES PRESENTED DIFFICULTIES; AND (4) THE ACTIVITIES WERE EXTENDED OVER TOO WIDE A GEOGRAPHIC AREA FOR THE NUMBER OF STAFF AVAILABLE. TO REMEDY THESE PROBLEMS THE EVALUATION TEAM SUGGESTS THAT PROJECT ACTIVITIES BE FOCUSED ON IMPROVING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION IN SPECIFIC, RESTRICTED ZONES. IN ADDITION. TO BETTER TEST THE SOUNDNESS OF THESE INTERVENTIONS, THE PROJECT'S DATA COLLECTION CAPABILITIES SHOULD BE IMPROVED. THIS EVALUATION REPORT ALSO PROVIDES MORE DETAILED DISCUSSION OF SPECIFIC PROJECT PROBLEMS (AGRICULTURAL PACKAGES, INPUTS, TRAINING PROGRAMS, CREDIT SYSTEMS, COOPERATIVES, GRINDING MILL INSTALLATION, TREE PLANTING, SOIL CONSERVATION, CHICKEN RAISING, AND GOAT AND CATTLE FATTENING) AND OFFERS RECOMMENDTIONS.

Abstract: EVALUATES THE CONCEPTUAL MODEL DEVELOPED BY SAN JOSE STATE UNIVERSITY KNOWN AS THE LEARNING RESOURCE CENTER-BASED COMMUNITY EDUCATION SYSTEM (LRC-BCES). THE LRC-BCES MODEL WAS DOCUMENTED IN THE SAN JOSE PAPER ENTITLED "FROM VISIONS TO DEVELOPMENT." THIS PAPER AND THE LRC-BCES CONCEPT WAS CONVEYED TO EDUCATORS FROM 6 LATIN AMERICAN COUNTRIES IN A WORKSHOP CONDUCTED IN JANUARY 1979. THE RESPONSES OF WORKSHOP PARTICIPANTS TO QUESTIONS CONCERNING THE LRC-BCES MODEL CONSTITUTE THE PRESENT EVALUATION. THE COUNTRY TEAMS UNANIMOUSLY BELIEVE THAT THE MODEL IS RELEVANT AND APPLICABLE TO THE EDUCATIONAL AND DEVELOPMENT PROBLEMS OF THEIR RESPECTIVE COUNTRIES. THE MODEL PRESENTS AN EFFECTIVE METHODOLOGY FOR TRANSLATING THE DEVELOPMENT GOALS OR "VISIONS" OF A COUNTRY INTO AN ACTION PROGRAM ADAPTED TO LOCAL COMMUNITY REALITIES. EACH COUNTRY TEAM BRIEFLY DESCRIBES THE DEVELOPMENT VISIONS OF THEIR COUNTRY, THE REALITIES OF THE RURAL POOR COMMUNITY, AND CURRENT PROGRAMS UNDERWAY TO ASSIST IN COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT. PARTICIPANTS THEN EXPLAIN HOW DIFFERENT ASPECTS OF THE LRC-BCES MODEL COULD BE ADAPTED TO IMPROVE EXISTING PROGRAMS AND ADDRESS DEVELOPMENT PROBLEMS. Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT TO INCREASE BEEF PRODUCTION THROUGH IMPROVED RANGE MANAGEMENT IN THE MAASAI REGION OF MALI AS OF 6/79. DEVELOPMENT ALTERNATIVES, INC PROVIDED 6 MAN-WEEKS OF TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE EVALUATION, WHICH WAS UNDERTAKEN IN MAY 1979. USAID HAS PROVIDED US $5 MILLION TO THE PROJECT, RESULTING IN A WIDE VARIETY OF OUTPUTS INCLUDING DEEP AND SHALLOW WELLS, DAMS, CATTLE DIPS, A RURAL TRAINING CENTER, PARTICIPANT TRAINING, VETERINARY SERVICES, STOCK IMPROVEMENT PROGRAMS, AND RANGE MANAGEMENT PLANS. THE NEAR EAST FOUNDATION HAS PROVIDED PROJECT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. LESSONS LEARNED DURING THIS PROJECT WERE NUMEROUS AND INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: (1) CHIEFS OF PARTY SHOULD HAVE PLANNING/MANAGEMENT/ADMINISTRATIVE CAPABILITIES AS WELL AS TECHNICAL EXPERTISE: (2) AUTHORITY SHOULD BE CONCENTRATED WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA WITH THE CHEIF OF PARTY AND HIS COUNTERPART AS CENTRAL ACTORS; (3) OVERALL A FLEXIBLE IMPLEMENTATION APPROACH MUST BE TAKEN, ESPECIALLY IN A 10-YEAR PROJECT; (4) A LIAISON OFFICE SHOULD BE ESTABLISHED IN THE PORT CITY TO FREE THE CHIEF OF PARTY FROM EXCESSIVE CONCENTRATION ON PROCUREMENTS; (5) PARTICIPANT TRAINING SHOULD BE AN INTEGRAL PART OF THE PROJECT ACTIVITIES; AND (6) RIGID MAINTENANCE AND INVENTORY OF VEHICLES ARE CRITICAL TO PROJECT SUCCESS. EVALUATORS ALSO NOTE THAT AN EXTENDED START-UP PERIOD IS NEEDED TO FOCUS ON LANGUAGE PROFICIENCY, KNOWLEDGE OF THE LOCALITY, AND DEVELOPMENT OF REPORTING PROCEDURES. IN ADDITION EXPATRIATE TECHNICIANS MUST BE WILLING TO WORK TOWARD THE DEVELOPMENT OF PROBLEM SOLUTIONS WHICH ARE FEASIBLE FOR TANZANIA RATHER THAN IMPORTING THE MOST ADVANCED TECHNIQUES OF THEIR PROFESSION.

Abstract: EVALUATES FROM 2/1/76 TO 6/1/79 MULTI-DONOR CENTRAL AFRICAN EMPIRE (CAE) SEED MULTIPLICATION PROJECT. PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO ESTABLISH AND INSTITUTIONALIZE A SEED PRODUCTION AND MULTIPLICATION CAPACITY AT THE GRIMARI AGRICULTURAL CENTER. EVALUATION, PREPARED BY AN OUTSIDE TEAM, IS BASED ON PROJECT DOCUMENTS, INFORMATION PROVIDED BY PROJECT AND GOCAE PERSONNEL, AND PERSONAL OBSERVATION. THE STATION AND FACILITIES AT GRIMARI ARE ALMOST COMPLETE. RICE SEED PRODUCTION (30 TONS) WAS ON TARGET IN 1978, BUT PEANUT SEED PRODUCTION (10 TONS) WAS ONLY 25% OFF TARGET. LATTER WILL BE INCREASED TO 20 TONS THIS YEAR. TRAINING OF CAE PERSONNEL IN SEED PRODUCTION PRACTICES HAS BEEN UNSTRUCTURED AND OF NEGLIGIBLE IMPACT. AID'S FARM MACHINERY SPECIALIST HAS BEEN ON SITE ONLY SINCE 5/78 DUE TO DIFFICULTY IN OBTAINING CAE OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE (O&M) PERSONNEL. HE HAS PERFORMED WELL, BUT IS OVEREXTENDED AND LACKS ADEQUATE TOOLS AND EQUIPMENT (NOW ON ORDER). HIS TRAINING OF O&M PERSONNEL HAS BEEN UNSTRUCTURED AND VERY LIMITED. SOME KEY PROJECT PAPER ASSUMPTIONS  -- GOCAE SUPPORT FR PROJECT, AND RECOGNIZED CONSTRANTS TO AGRICULTURAL PROUDUCTION -- ARE INVALID OR HIGHLY QUESTIONABLE. THESE DOUBTS AFFECT PROJECT GOAL AND PURPOSE. IF PHASE II OF THE PROJECT IS TO BE SUCCESSFUL, THERE WILL HAVE TO BE SUBSTANTIAL INCREASES IN MARKETING AND DISTRIBUTION, AGRICULTURAL EXTENSION, AND IN EDUCATION OF FARMERS IN IMPROVED AGRONOMIC PRACTICES. IN ADDITION, GOCAE WILL HAVE TO PROVIDE SOLID SUPPORT TO THE PROJECT. UNDER PRESENT CONDITIONS, THE PROJECT HAS LITTLE CHANCE OF SUCCEEDING ON TIME AND EQUIPMENT AND THE CENTER ITSELF WILL MOST PROBABLY DETERIORATE AFTER EXPATRIATE PERSONNEL WITHDRAW. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT: (1) AID'S TECHNICIANS REMAIN FOR A YEAR, RESTRICTING HIS ACTIVITIES TO DEVELOPING AN ADEQUATE O&M CAPABILITY, ESPECIALLY IN REGARD TO US MACHINERY, AND TO MONITORING, ASSESSING, AND ADVISING ON LOCAL USE OF MACHINERY; AND (2) AID DISCONTINUE FUNDING AFTER FY 79-80 UNLESS SUBSTANTIAL CHANGES ARE MADE IN THE CONCEPTION AND DESIGN OF PHASE II OF THE PROJECT.

Abstract: FINAL REPORT ON THE RICE PRODUCTION ACCELERATED IMPACT PROJECT (AIP) IN GUINEA-BISSAU (GB) EVALUATES PROJECT SUCCESS IN INCREASING RICE OUTPUT OF PEASANTS IN THE CONTUBOEL AND SAUCUNDA REGIONS BY USE OF SELECTED SEEDS, FERTILIZER, AND DRY-SEASON IRRIGATION. DATA USED IN THE EVALUATION PROCESS IS DERIVED FROM DISCUSSIONS WITH FARM FAMILY PARTICIPANTS, AGRI EXTENSION AGENTS, AND THE DIRECTOR OF GOGB'S DEPT OF RICE EXPERIMENTATION & PRODUCTION (DEPA). HYDROLOGISTS ALSO CONTRIBUTED TECH OPINIONS ON OVERALL IRRIGATION PROJECT (ATTACHED). THE RICE PRODUCTION AIP PROJECT HAS PROVEN SUCCESSFUL IN ENLISTING THE SUPPORT OF RURAL PEASANTS IN 2-SEASON INTENSIVE IRRIGATED RICE CULTIVATION. THE ORIGINAL TARGET OF ENROLLING 150 PEASANT FAMILIES IN RICE CULTIVATION PRACTICES HAS BEEN EASILY SURPASSED, AND PROJECT ACTIVITIES HAVE BROUGHT HIGHER PER HECTARE RICE YIELDS, HIGHER PER CAPITA CONSUMPTION, AND APPROX FOOD SELF-SUFFICIENCY TO PARTICIPANTS. IN 1978, 195 FAMILIES CULTIVATED 80 HECTARES (AVG 0.41 HA/FAMILY) IN THE DRY SEASON, AND 508 FAMILIEIS CULTIVATED 166 HECTARES IN THERAINY SEASON (AVG 0.33 HA/FAMILY). THE ENTHUSIASTIC RESPONSE FROM PARTICIPANTS STEMS FROM IMPRESSIVE RICE YIELDS OBTAINED IN THE DRY SEASON, ABSENCE OF INDEBTEDNESS, NON-COMPULSION, LOW RISKS, AND THE SMALL-SCALE ORGANIZATION OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES. THERE REMAIN 4 MAJOR PROBLEMS IN THE PROJECT WHICH MUST BE RESOLVED, PARTICULARLY IF PROJECT IS TO BE EXPANDED: (1)THE LACK OF FINANCIAL ACCOUNTABILITY FOR PROJECT COSTS BY PEASANT PRODUCERS; (2)THE ABSENCE OF REAL TECH & MANAGERIAL RESPONSIBILITY EXERCISED BY PRODUCERS' ASSOC; (3)THE FAILURE TO CONSIDER MEASURES WHICH COULD CAPITALIZE ON PROJECT'S ABILITY TO IMPROVE WOMEN'S ECONOMIC STATUS; (4)THE INADEQUATE SYSTEM FOR DOCUMENTING EVOLUTION OF PEASANT PERIMETERS. RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE DESIGN OF PROJECT EXPANSION INCLUDE: (1)PREPARATION/MGMT OF PERIMETER TOPOGRAPHY; (2)ACTUAL & POTENTIAL MKT POSSIBILITIES FOR RICE, SORGHUM & MILLET PROD;(3)ARRANGEMENT FOR COST ACCTNG SYSTEM FOR PROJ. APPENDICES INCLUDE PROJECT DATA ON HECTARES OF LAND CULTIVATED, FAMILY COMPOSITION, AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS. MAPS INCLUDED.

Abstract: EVALUATES FROM 1/77 TO 5/79 PROJECT TO DEMONSTRATE USE OF NEW REMOTE SENSING TECHNOLOGY/TECHNIQUES TO ASSESS AND MANAGE AGRICULTURAL AND OTHER RESOURCES IN LDC'S. EVALUATION, PREPARED BY A CONTRACTOR AND ATTACHED TO PES (PD-AAG-397-B1), IS BASED ON REVIEW OF PROJECT DESIGN, COUNTRY VISITS, AND INTERVIEWS WITH PROJECT PERSONNEL). DESPITE GENERALLY GOOD PERFORMANCE OF THE ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH INSTITUTE OF MICHIGAN (ERIM) -- THOUGH SUB-PROJECT MANAGEMENT DIFFERED WIDELY -- SMALL GRANTS PROGRAM HAD ONLY MIXED SUCCESS. SUB-PROJECT IN BOLIVIA FAILED TECHNICALLY, PARTIALLY DUE TO UNDERFUNDING AND AN INAPPROPRIATE CHOICE OF RECIPIENT AGENCY. SUB-PROJECT IN PERU WAS TECHNICALLY SUCCESSFUL AND GENERATED ENTHUSIASM. A SECOND GRANT IS PLANNED. A REGIONAL SEMINAR HELD IN PERU WAS ONLY PARTIALLY A SUCCESS, DUE TO POOR PLANNING. (THE INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM IN MANILA, HOWEVER, WAS A GREAT SUCCESS). SUB-PROJECT IN THAILAND WAS NOT GENERALLY SUCCESSFUL,  DUE IN PART TO THE FAILURE TO CORRELATE TIMES FOR GATHERING LANDSAT AND GROUND TRUTH DATA. THE RECIPINET AGENCY, HOWEVER, GAINED VALUABLE EXPERIENCE. SUB-PROJECT IN SRI LANKA WAS A SUCCESS AND THE TECHNICAL CAPABILITY OF THE RECIPENT AGENCY WAS ENHANCED. EVALUATIONS RECEIVED FROM PHILIPPINE PERSONNEL (THE COUNTRY WAS NOT VISITED) CONTRADICT, SEEMINGLY WITH REASON, AID ASSURANCES OF SUB-PROJECT SUCCESS IN THAT COUNTRY. SMALL GRANTS MECHANISM IS GENERALLY VALID, BUT IS BEST ADAPTED TO INTRODUCING NEW TECHNOLOGY. CONCOMITANT TRAINING SHOULD BE KEPT AT AN APPROPRIATE LEVEL AND SHOULD BE HELD IN THE HOST COUNTRY. TRAINING PROGRAMS HELD AT SOUTH DAKOTA STATE UNIVERSITY FOR NEPALESE PERSONNEL WERE A SUCCESS. FUTURE TRAINING FOR SUDANESE AND SENGALESE PERSONNEL IS PLANNED. PROJECT DESIGN IS BASICALLY SOUND, BUT COULD BE IMPROVED BY GREATER SPECIFICATION AT THE GOAL AND OUTPUTS LEVELS. CLOSER TIES BETWEEN CONTRACTOR, USAID'S, AND LDC AGENCIES, AS WELL AS INCREASED FUNDING FOR TRAVEL, ARE ALSO RECOMMENDED. FUTURE PROJECTS SHOULD INCLUDE A CONCLUDING SEMINAR TO ENSURE DIFFUSION OF PROJECT RESULTS. AN EXTENSIVE BIBLIOGRAPHY IS INCLUDED.

Abstract: EVALUATES LATIN AMERICAN PROJECT ACTIVITIES OF THE PATHFINDER FUND (PF) AS OF 2/27/79 BASED ON FIELD VISITS. THE RAPID INCREASE OF INTEREST IN AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR FAMILY PLANNING IN LATIN AMERICA HAS RESULTED IN THE NEED FOR MORE FREQUENT AND LONGER VISITS BY PF REPRESENTATIVES. THIS WILL BE FACILITATED BY THE PLANNED RECRUITMENT OF REPRESENTATIVES IN MEXICO, BRAZIL, AND PERU. THE LATIN AMERICA/NORTH OFFICE SEEMS TO BE WELL LOCATED FOR ITS RESPONSIBILITIES. THIS IS NOT TRUE OF THE LATIN AMERICA/SOUTH OFFICE BECAUSE THE OPPORTUNITIES ARE IN THE NORTH AND EAST. THIS IS NOT LIKELY TO CHANGE SINCE BOTH ARGENTINA AND CHILE ARE APPROACHING THE STATE OF FEELING COMPETENT TO HANDLE THEIR OWN POPULATION PROBLEMS. THE FOCUS IN LATIN AMERICA IS ON VOLUNTARY FAMILY PLANNING GROUPS, USING PROFESSORS OF OBSTETRICS, AND ON THE TRAINING OF PARA-MEDICAL WOMEN WORKERS AND PHYSICIANS IN LOW TECHNOLOGY STERILIZATION. PF MAY NEED MORE STAFF IN STERILIZATION, TRAINING, AND CONTRACEPTION IN GENERAL, ESPECIALLY AS NEW PROJECTS AND INITIATIVES DEVELOP. SEVERAL PROJECTS COULD BENEFIT FROM MORE CAREFUL ASSESSMENT AND EVALUATION; IT IS NOT CLEAR THAT PF REGIONAL OFFICES HAVE NECESSARY SKILLS TO PROVIDE THIS SERVICE. IF NOT, THEY MUST UTILIZE AVAILABLE STAFF SKILLS IN MEETING THIS NEED. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT: 1)PF SHOULD CONTINUE ITS TRADITIONAL ROLE OF SUPPORTING INNOVATION, SHORT-TERM AND HIGH RISK PROJECTS WHERE THESE ARE STILL NEEDED, BUT ALSO SHOULD SUPPORT LARGER AND LONGER TERM PROJECTS. PF SHOULD REVIEW ITS COMMUNITY-BASED DISTRIBUTION PROJECTS TO DETERMINE THE NEED FOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO IMPROVE ADMINISTRATION OR TO PROMOTE INNOVATION.

Abstract: 3/30-4/18/79 SERIES OF INTEROFFICE MEMORANDA-GENERATED SPECIAL EVALUATION OF USAID LOAN-SUPPORTED, SMALL-SCALE IRRIGATION PROJECT IN BANGLADESH ASSESSES ALTERNATIVES FOR PROCUREMENT, ASSEMBLY, AND DISTRIBUTION OF HAND PUMPS AND ACCESSORIES. PROJ DESIGNED TO ASSIST SMALL FARMERS ACQUIRE OWNERSHIP OF SMALL-SCALE IRRIGATION EQUIPMENT, WITH CURRENT EMPHASIS ON PUMP PRODUCTION. INDEPTH MISSION ASSESSMENT BASED ON EXTENSIVE RESEARCH AND ON DISCUSSIONS WITH BANGLADESH ASSISTING AGENCIES, UNICEF & OTHER PVO'S INVOLVED IN SIMILAR VENTURES, AND WITH AMMANN & WHITNEY, THE PROJ'S CONSULTANT ENGINEERS. EVAL ANTICIPATES MAJOR IMPORT PROCUREMENT PROBLEM FOR OFFSHORE COMMODITIES,WITH BANGLADESH AGENCIES EXPECTED TO PROVIDE SLOW AND UNRELIABLE SERVICE. LOCALLY-PRODUCED PIPE IS NOT AT THIS POINT REGARDED A VIABLE SUBSTITUTE FOR IMPORTED PIPE (STEEL OR PLSTIC) AS UNICEF HAS FOUND IT TO BE OF SUBSTANDARD QUALITY. LIKEWISE,LOCALLY-PRODUCED BRASS SHEET AND BRASS WIRE CLOTH ARE ALSO JUDGED TO BE SUBSTANDARD IN THE PRODUCTION OF STRAINERS. EVAL RECOMMENDS: 1)ARRANGEMENT WHEREBY BANGLADESH AGRIC DVLP CORP (BADC) AND TRADING CORP OF BANGLADESH RELEASE IMPORTED RAW MATERIALS TO FOUNDRIES FROM PRESENT STOCK WITH THE UNDERSTANDING THAT PROJ WILL FINANCE REPLENISHMENT OF STOCKS; 2)REVIEW WITH BADC,CONSTRAINTS AND POTENTIAL SOLUTIONS TO STEPS NOW REQUIRED TO PROCURE BOTH LOCAL & IMPORTED MATERIALS;AND 3)THAT IMPORTED PLASTIC PIPE & STRAINERS MIGHT WELL BE CONSIDERED TO OFFER THE FARMER AS AN ALTERNATIVE TO IMPORTED STEEL PIPE & BRASS STRAINERS. EVAL ALSO RECOMMENDS THAT PLANNING & FOLLOW-UP ACTION BE UNDERTAKEN TO ENCOURAGE SALE & DISTRIBUTION OF PUMPS BY PRIVATE DEALERS;THAT QUOTAS FOR PUMP DISTRIBUTION BE ALLOCATED TO THANA ADMIN UNITS;THAT CREDIT DETAILS & BANK LENDING PROCEDURES BE WORKED OUT;THAT SPARE PARTS & MAINTENANCE PLAN BE DEVELOPED;AND THAT SPECIAL EFFORTS BE INSTITUTED TO REACH SMALL FARMER TARGET GROUP. HERE,PVO'S MIGHT WELL BE UTILIZED TO REACH ACTUAL TARGET GROUP. REVISED COST ESTIMATES INDICATE 175,000 PUMP SETS RATHER THAN THE ORIGINALLY-PLANNED 240,000,TO BE MORE WITHIN THE SCOPE OF THE USAID LOAN.

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT TO PRODUCE A MANUAL ON ROAD NETWORK DEVELOPMENT PLANNING (RNDP) TECHNIQUES FOR INTERMEDIATE SIZE PHILIPPINE CITIES, USING TESTED FIELD TECHNIQUES; AND TO DEVISE A TRAINING PROGRAM FEATURING THE MANUAL. ALTHOUGH RNDP MANUAL WAS COMPLETED ON SCHEDULE, THE PILOT PROJECT STUDY (PPS) AT ANGELES CITY TO DETERMINE AND SOLVE ROAD TRANSPORTATION PROBLEMS WAS UNSUCCESSFUL. THE PPS LACKED ADEQUATELY TRAINED STAFF TO COMPLETE THE PPS IN THE ALLOTED 3 MONTHS TIME, DUE TO COMPLEX DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS PROCESSES. STAFF ALSO WERE UNABLE TO DEVELOP A TRAINING PROGRAM FOR GOVT OF PHILIPPINE (GOP) PERSONNEL. IT WAS DIFFICULT TO CONFORM TO ANY RESEARCH SCHEDULE DUE TO THE PROJECT'S INITIAL INVESTIGATORY NATURE AND INFLEXIBLE GOP PERSONNEL SCHEDULES. THE MAIN TRANSPORTATION DEVELOPMENT PROBLEM, HOWEVER, WAS CITY DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE PROJECT (CDAP) PERSONNEL'S INSUFFICIENT KNOWLEDGE OF THE FORCES SHAPING CITY DEVELOPMENT AND DICTATING THE TYPES AND LOCATION OF FUTURE LAND USES. DESPITE THE GENERAL LACK OF PROGRESS, EVALUATOR FEELS RNDP, PPS PARTICIPANTS HAVE RECEIVED SUFFICIENT TRAINING TO INDEPENDENTLY CONDUCT RNDP STUDIES ON A SMALLER SCALE THAN THE ANGELES CITY PPS. IN FUTURE RNDP STUDIES, HOWEVER, SUFFICIENT TIME SHOULD BE ALLOWED FOR PROJECT COMPLETION. ALSO, IF STUDY PROCEDURES WERE SIMPLIFIED CDAP STAFF COULD MORE EFFECTIVELY ANALYZE THE VOLUME AND CAPACITY OF ALL MAIN ROADS TO DETERMINE WHICH ROADS WERE OPERATING AT OR ABOVE CAPACITY BETWEEN 6-8 AM AND 4-6 PM. SINCE OTHER FACTORS THAN TRAFFIC FLOW, SUCH AS CONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES NEAR ROADS PREVENT WIDENING ROADWAYS, SUCH FACTORS SHOULD BE DETERMINED AND UNDERSTOOD BY GOP PERSONNEL. RNDP PLANNING PROCESS COULD BE SIMPLIFIED FOR ALL CITIES BY DEVELOPING TRAFFIC REGULATIONS IN RELATION TO LAND USE AND TO ADJACENT ROUTES. LAND USE STUDIES WOULD ALSO MAKE IT POSSIBLE TO PREDICT TRAFFIC VOLUMES IN RELATION TO LAND USE AND, WHERE NEEDED, TO DESIGN ROAD SECTIONS OF ADEQUATE CAPACITY TO HANDLE INCREASED TRAFFIC FLOW.

Abstract: EVALUATES FROM 6/76 TO 5/79 PROJECT TO CONSTRUCT 940 KMS OF ALL-WEATHER AGRICULTURAL FEEDER ROADS IN HAITI, WHILE STRENGTHENING THE INSTITUTIONAL CAPABILITY OF THE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS, TRANSPORTATION, AND COMMUNICATION (TPTC). EVALUATION, PREPARED BY AN OUTSIDE TEAM AT MISSION REQUEST AND ATTACHED TO PROJECT PES (PD-AAB-706-A1), IS BASED ON PROJECT DOCUMENTS, INTERVIEWS WITH PROJECT PERSONNEL, AND FIELD VISITS. GOH SUPPORT HAS BEEN WEAK. TPTC, DESPITE TECHNICAL ABILITY, HAS LACKED ORGANIZATION, MANAGEMENT, AND MOTIVATION, ESPECIALLY REGARDING THE LABOR-INTENSIVE PILOT PROJECT. PROJECT HAS BEEN CONSIDERABLY DELAYED THEREBY, AS WELL AS BY FAULTY PROJECT DESIGN (INCLUDING UNEVEN TECHNICAL STANDARDS), LACK OF UNIFIED MANAGEMENT, AND PROCUREMENT DELAYS. AS OF 3/31/79, ONLY 87 OF PROJECTED 371.5 KMS HAVE BEEN BUILT. LABOR-INTENSIVE METHODS HAVE BEEN COSTLIER THAN ANTICIPATED. A DECISION ON THEIR CONTINUANCE MUST BE MADE. NEW ROADS HAVE PROVIDED ACCESS TO A WIDE RANGE OF GOODS AND SERVICES, ALTHOUGH CAUSING DISCONTENT DUE TO LOW RATE OF EMPLOYMENT OF LOCALS IN CONSTRUCTION WORK. CONTRACTOR HAS BEEN ADEQUATE IN PROVIDING ENGINEERING ASSISTANCE, LESS SO IN HELPING TPTC REORGANIZE. PARTLY DUE TO LACK OF PROJECT PAPER SPECIFICATION, TRAINING HAS BEEN MOSTLY ON-THE-JOB. CONTRACTOR HAD NO PREVIOUS EXPERIENCE WITH LABOR-INTENSIVE METHODS AND PROVIDED NO COST COMPARISON OF LABOR AND MACHINE-INTENSIVE METHODS. RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDE: DECISION ON WHETHER PRIMARY PROJECT PURPOSE IS ROAD CONSTRUCTION OR INSTITUTION-BUILDING; GREATER SUPPORT FOR TPTC REORGANIZATION AND INTEGRATION; REASSESSMENTS OF GOH COMMITMENT AND OF TECHNICAL SURVEY AND PRIVATE CONTRACTOR COSTS; A REVISED CONSTRUCTION STRATEGY BASED ON A MIX OF LABOR AND MACHINE-INTENSIVE METHODS; A NEW TRAINING PROGRAM, INCLUDING MANAGEMENT TRAINING, FOR TPTC; ELIMINATION OF PROCUREMENT DELAYS; CONDUCT OF A BASELINE SOCIO-ECONOMIC SURVEY TO MEASURE PROJECT IMPACT AND OF AN AUDIT TO COMPARE REAL AND PROJECTED COSTS; CONTINUANCE OF MAJOR CONSULTANT SERVICES, TOGETHER WITH STRONG COUNTERPART DIRECTION; AND PROJECT EVALUATION IN ONE YEAR.

Abstract: EVALUATES THROUGH 3/79 ACADEMIC COMPONENT OF LOAN AND GRANT TO THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF THE PHILIPPINES (GOP) TO INCREASE SMALL FARMER PRODUCTIVITY AND MARKETING EFFICIENCY. COMPONENT PURPOSE IS TO DEVELOP A CADRE OF TRAINED PROFESSIONALS FOR PUBLIC AND PRIVATE AGRICULTURAL AGENCIES AND INSTITUTIONS. EVALUATION, PREPARED BY AN OUTSIDE TEAM AT GOP'S REQUEST, IS BASED ON PROJECT DOCUMENTS, INTERVIEWS WITH PERSSONNEL FROM CONCERNED INSTITUTIONS, AND REACTIONS OF PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION UNITS TO ORIGINAL EVALUATION DRAFT. OVERSEAS MA AND PHD TRAINING AND POST-DOCTORAL FELLOWSHIPS FOR STAFFS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF THE PHILIPPINES AT LOS BANOS (UPLB) AND CENTRAL LUZON STATE UNIVERSITY (CLSU) ARE CONSIDERABLY BEHIND SCHEDULE. IT IS THEREFORE RECOMMENDED THAT GRADUATE TRAINING BE DONE IN-COUNTRY TO AVOID THE GOVERNMENT SERVICE REQUIREMENT AND TO REDUCE COSTS, WITH THE OPPORTUNITY FOR PHD CANDIDATES TO SPEND A YEAR ABROAD TO MINIMIZE INBREEDING; THAT THE TIME FOR MS AND PHD TRAINING BE EXTENDED TO 16 AND 36 MONTHS, RESPECTIVELY; AND THAT THE STIPEND FOR FELLOWSHIPS BE INCREASED OR THE PROGRAM AS A WHOLE BE REPLACED BY IN-COUNTRY, SHORT-TERM TRAINING COURSES INCORPORATING FOREIGN TRAINERS. SHORT TRAINING COURSES AT BOTH SCHOOLS ARE PROGRESSING WELL, BUT SHOULD BE STRENGTHENED BY GREATER INVOLVEMENT OF TARGET CLIENTELE IN PROGRAM DESIGN, BY POST-PLANNING EVALUATIONS, AND BY ASSURANCE OF CONTINUING GOP FINANCIAL SUPPORT. INPUTS SHOULD BE SOUGHT FROM THE PRIVATE SECTOR IN THE ARE A OF CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT. ALSO, MAKING FOOD SYSTEMS A MAJOR WITHIN EXISTING PROGRAMS SEEMS PREFERABLE TO CREATING NEW DEGREE PROGRAMS. UPLB'S TARGET OF MS'S IN AGRICULTURAL MARKETING SHOULD BE REDUCED FROM 50 TO 30 AND CLSU'S TARGET OF 25 MARKETING MAJORS SHOULD BE INCREASED TO 35/40. THE ACADEMIC COMPONENT AS A WHOLE SHOULD BE EXPANDED TO INCLUDE TRAINING OF EXTENSION STUDENTS AND AGENTS FOR THE TECHNOLOGICAL COMPONENT OF THE PROJECT. ALL CURRENT AND PROPOSED DEGREE AND NON-DEGREE TRAINING PROGRAMS SHOULD BE EVALUATED IN THE LIGHT OF PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND AUGMENTED BY IN-COUNTRY EXPERIENCE.

Abstract: EVALUATES THROUGH 3/79 TECHNOLOGICAL PACKAGE (TECH PACK) COMPONENT OF LOAN AND GRANT TO THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF THE PHILIPPINES TO INCREASE SMALL FARMER PRODUCTIVITY AND MARKETING EFFICIENCY. COMPONENT PURPOSE IS TO DEVELOP THE CAPACITY OF CENTRAL LUZON STATE UNIVERSITY (CLSU) TO DESIGN AND TEST OPERATIONALLY INTEGRATED PACKAGES OF PRODUCTION, PROCESSING, AND MARKETING TECHNOLOGY. EVALUATION, PREPARED BY AN OUTSIDE TEAM AT GORP'S REQUEST, IS BASED ON PROJECT DOCUMENTS, INTERVIEWS WITH PERSONNEL FROM CONCERNED INSTITUTIONS, AND REACTIONS OF PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION UNITS TO THE ORIGINAL EVALUATION DRAFT. CONSULTANT NEEDS OF CLSU SHOULD BE REVIEWED IN LIGHT OF THE SCHEDULED DEPARTURE OF PRESENT CONSULTANTS. A PLANNING PERIOD FOR ALL CONSULTANTS IS ADVISED IN LIGHT OF DELAYS THAT HAVE OCCURRED. GRADUATE TRAINING IN US IS AHEAD OF SCHEDULE. CLSU'S SOCIO-ECONOMIC RESEARCH UNIT CONDUCTED A BASELINE SURVEY OF 18 REPRESENTATIVE BARRIOS. ADDITIONAL DATA ARE NOW NEEDED TO LAY A BASIS FOR AN INTEGRATED TECH PACK. SEVERAL OTHER STUDIES ARE ALSO UNDERWAY. THE TECH PACK TESTING AND ADOPTION GROUP HAS CONDUCTED RESEARCH IN A WIDE VARIETY OF AREAS, ESPECIALLY IN CROPPING SYSTEMS, AND IS GAINING PRACTICAL MARKETING EXPERIENCE IN WORK WITH ONION FARMERS. TECH PACKS SHOULD BE DEVELOPED FOR SUBSISTENCE PURPOSES AS A CUSHION AGAINST MARKET FAILURES, AND EXTENSION WORKERS SHOULD PROVIDE FEEDBACK FROM FARMERS TO AID IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF TECH PACKS. THE TECH PACK ADVISORY COMMITTEE SHOULD BE ACTIVATED TO PROVIDE OVERALL GUIDANCE. CONSTRUCTION OF THE 2 BUILDINGS OF THE FOOD AND FEED PROCESSING CENTER IS UNDERWAY. PARTICIPANT TRAINING NEEDS, ESPECIALLY IN FOOD PRODUCTION, SHOULD BE STUDIED, AND A LONG-TERM FOOD SCIENCE EXPERT SHOULD BE ENGAGED FOR TRAINING NEEDS. A PAPER ON THE CAPACITY, STAFF, AND TRAINING NEEDS OF THE FEED MILL HAS BEEN PREPARED. TECH PACK COMPONENT CAN BE IMPROVED BY COORDINATING IT WITH THE 4 AREAS SELECTED FOR THE PROJECT'S EXTENSION COMPONENT. THE FEASIBILITY OF THE PROPOSAL FOR STUDENTS' COOPERATIVES TO RUN THE UNIVERSITY FARM AND PROCESSING CENTER SHOULD BE REVIEWED AND ALTERNATIVES STUDIES.

Abstract: EVALUATES THROUGH 3/79 EXTENSION/OUTREACH COMPONENT OF LOAN AND GRANT TO THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF THE PHILIPPINES (GRP) TO INCREASE SMALL FARMER PRODUCTIVITY AND MARKETING EFFICIENCY. COMPONENT PURPOSE IS TO DEVELOP IMPROVED OUTREACH PROGRAMS FOR SMALLER FARMER PRODUCERS AND AGRIBUSINESS ENTERPRISES AND TO IMPROVE THE PLANNING AND POLICY CAPABILITY OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE INSTITUTIONS IN THE SECTOR. EVALUATION, PREPARED BY AN OUTSIDE TEAM AT GRP'S REQUEST, IS BASED ON PROJECT DOCUMENTS, INTERVIEWS WITH PERSONNEL FROM CONCERNED INSTITUTIONS, AND REACTIONS OF PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION UNIT TO ORIGINAL EVALUATION DRAFT. PROGRESS TO DATE HAS BEEN SLOW, DUE IN PART TO NON-OPERATION OF THE OVERVIEW COMMITTEE. ACTIVITES SHOULD INCREASE WITH RECENT ARRIVAL OF EXTENSION CONSULTANT. ACTIVITIES HAVE INCLUDED ESTABLISHMENT OF REGIONAL PROFILES AND OF A MARKETING ASSISTANCE CENTER; CONDUCT OF A BASELINE SURVEY ON VEGETABLE PRODUCTION AND MARKETING; AND SHORT-TERM TRAINING OF TECHNICIANS FOR MARKETING CENTER OPERATIONS. IN REGARD TO THE LATTER, BOTH DEGREE AND NON-DEGREE PROGRAMS ARE NEEDED IN FOOD TECHNOLOGY AND PROCESSING. A SPECIALIST AND STAFF SHOULD BE ENGAGED FOR THIS. MS TRAINING HAS BEEN PROVIDED TO 8 INDIVIDUALS. A PLAN FOR THE REMAINING 23 SLOTS SHOULD BE DEVELOPED. NON-DEGREE TRAINING IS BASICALLY ON SCHEDULE. Abstract: EVALUATES THROUGH 3/79 OVERALL MANAGEMENT OF PROJECT TO INCREASE SMALL FARMER PRODUCTIVITY AND MARKETING EFFICIENCY IN THE PHILIPPINES. IN THE AREA OF DIRECTION AND CONTROL, STEPS SHOULD BE TAKEN TO ENABLE KSU TO ESTABLISH FORMAL WORKING RELATIONSHIPS WITH OTHER US UNIVERSITIES TO AUGMENT THE SCOPE AND QUALITY OF ITS STAFF. Abstract: EVALUATES FROM 7/78 TO 9/79 LOAN TO THE GOVERNMENT OF COSTA RICE TO DEVELOP AN INTEGRATED AND MULTI-SECTORAL NATIONAL NUTRITION PROGRAM. Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT TO PROMOTE THE EFFICIENT UTILIZATION OF FEEDSTUFFS OR FEEDING SYSTEMS FOR VARIOUS CLASSES OF ANIMAL SPECIES IN LDC'S DURING FY 78 AND FY 79. EVALUATION WAS COMPILED THROUGH AN ONSITE VISIT TO THE INTERNATIONAL FEEDSTUFFS INSTITUTE (IFI) PROGRAM, ORAL REPORTS FROM IFI STAFF, AND REVIEW OF INFORMATION SUPPLIED BY IFI STAFF. EXCELLENT PROGRESS WAS MADE TOWARD PROJECT GOALS. THE INTERNATIONAL FEED VOCABULARY WAS IMPROVED AND SIMPLIFIED; FEED NAMES WERE EDITED AND CORRECTIONS WERE MADE IN SCIENTIFIC AND COMMON NAMES. MORE THAN 1300 FEED NAMES WITH COMPOSITION DATA HAVE BEEN ADDED FROM THE MIDDLE EAST AND SOUTHEAST ASIA BRINGING THE TOTAL TO 13,480 FEED ENTRIES IN THE DATA BANK. FEED INFORMATION CENTERS HAVE BEEN ESTABLISHED IN SYRIA, SERVING 21 ARAB COUNTRIES, AND IN COSTA RICA, SERVING 21 LATIN AMERICAN COUNTRIES. A CONSTITUTION AND BY-LAWS HAVE BEEN PREPARED FOR AN INTERNATIONAL NETWORK OF FEED INFORMATION CENTERS (INFIC), AND A SECRETARIAT IS UNDER CONSIDERATION TO FURTHER SOLIDIFY INFIC. ABOUT 1100 KEY PEOPLE ATTENDED WORKSHOPS, SYMPOSIA, TRAINING SESSIONS, AND MEETINGS. TWENTY-THREE ARTICLES WERE PUBLISHED CONCERNING IFI ACTIVITIES, AND 12 ADDITIONAL PAPERS DEALING WITH INFIC AIMS AND GOALS WERE PRESENTED IN 4 COUNTRIES. ALSO MORE THAN 1000 COPIES OF THE "INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON FEED COMPOSITION, ANIMAL NUTRIENT REQUIREMENTS AND COMPUTERIZATION OF DIETS" HAVE BEEN SOLD. GRADUATE STUDENT TRAINING WAS CONTINUED WITH 3 STUDENTS SUPPORTED PARTIALLY ON THE PROJECT. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT THE PROJECT BE EXTENDED FOR 3 TO 5 YEARS TO COMPLETE WORK ON THE ORIGINAL OBJECTIVES AND TO INCREASE TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES. IT IS ALSO RECOMMENDED THAT THE CONTRACTOR ASSIST WITH INCREASING THE UTILIZATION OF THE IN FORMATION GENERATED BY THE PROJECT, AND THAT ATTENTION BE FOCUSED ON THE QUALITY OF THE DATA INPUT INTO THE DATA BANK. IN ADDITION, NEW FEED COMPOSITION DATA ON MORE FEED STUFFS WILL BE NEEDED TO FILL DATA GAPS. ESTABLISHMENT OF AN INFIC SECRETARIAT IS ALSO RECOMMENDED. Abstract: EVALUATES PROGRESS OF THE COSTA RICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE CONSERVATION OF NATURE(ASCONA) FROM 9/78 TO 10/79 IN PROMOTING NATIONAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION BASED ON THE OBSERVATIONS OF AN INDEPENDENT CONSULTANT. THE MOTTO AND BEACON OF ASCONA IS "DEVELOPMENT WITHOUT DESTRUCTION". THE ORGANIZATION HAS TWO FUNDAMENTAL GOALS: (1) CONSERVATION EDUCATION FOR THE YOUTH AND GENERAL PUBLIC, AND (2) FORCEFUL ACTION AGAINST THOSE IN COSTA RICA WHO DISREGARD ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY AND RESOURCE CONSERVATION FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS. PRIOR TO THE OPERATIONAL PROGRAM GRANT, ASCONA OPERATED ON A MEAGER BUDGET WITH ONLY VOLUNTEER SERVICES. THE ORGANIZATION HAS SHOWN SIGNS, HOWEVER, OF SOCIO-POLITICAL INFLUENCE REGARDING COSTA RICAN ENVIRONMENTAL AND CONSERVATION ISSUES. ASCONA HAS HIRED A FULL-TIME EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, A FIVE-MEMBER TECHNICAL/EDUCATIONAL STAFF, AND SOME CLERICAL PERSONNEL. THOUGH ONLY HALFWAY THROUGH THE GRANT PERIOD, ASCONA'S MEMBERSHIP AND DONATION INCOME HAS INCREASED DRAMATICALLY, ITS VOICE IS HEARD ALMOST DAILY ON TELEVISION, ON RADIO, OR IN THE PRESS, AND ITS INFLUENCE IS REACHING HIGH LEVELS OF GOVERNMENT. THE EVALUATION PROVIDES A NUMBER OR RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ASCONA. (1) HIRE ADDITIONAL STAFF IN CONSERVATION EDUCATION AND IN FUNDRAISING. (2) EXPAND LIBRARY COLLECTIONS OF BOOKS, JOURNALS, ARTICLES, AND AUDIO-VISUAL MATERIALS. (3) CONSIDER ADDITION OF A STUDENT MEMBERSHIP FOR ASCONA. (4) REQUEST FUNDING TO CREATE A MODEST WATER QUALITY LABORATORY AND/OR AN AIR QUALITY LABORATORY. (5) SEEK FUNDING FOR A VEHICLE FOR EDUCATIONAL AND INVESTIGATIVE ACTIVITIES. (6) MAINTAIN A DAILY LOG OF ALL ASCONA ACTIVITIES. (7) PREPARE SIMPLE, ILLUSTRATED BOOKLETS FOR SCHOOL CHILDREN WHICH DEAL WITH CONSERVATION TOPICS. (8) EXPAND LEGAL SERVICES. (9) MAINTAIN OR INTENSIFY THE ATTACK AGAINST THOSE PERSONS AND INSTITUTIONS IN COSTA RICA WHO IGNORE CONSERVATION. RECOMMENDATIONS ARE ALSO PROVIDED FOR USAID/CR. FUTURE OPG'S TO SMALL, PRIVATE GROUPS SHOULD ALLOW UP TO SIX-MONTH START-UP PERIOD. CLOSE LIAISON BETWEEN AID STAFF AND ASCONA SHOULD BE CONSIDERED. THIS EVALUATION IS APPENDED TO PES 5150142001502.

Abstract: REPORTS ON PROJECT TO INSTITUTE EYE CARE SERVICES IN THE CENTRAL AND RIFT VALLEY PROVINCES OF KENYA DURING THE PERIOD 1/1/78 TO 12/31/78. THE EDUCATIONAL CAPABILITIES OF THE MOBILE EYE UNITS (MEU'S) WERE EXPANDED WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF A PRIMARY HEALTH CARE MANUAL AND AN IMPROVED VERSION OF A VISUAL ACUITY CHART WITH EYE CARE MESSAGES PRINTED ON IT. INTERNATIONAL EYE FOUNDATION (IEF) OPHTHALMOLOGISTS ARE SUPERVISING, DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY, 22 OF KENYA'S 27 MOBILE AND STATIC EYE UNITS. IEF HAS PROVIDED DIAGNOSTIC EQUIPMENT AND THERAPEUTIC AND EXPENDABLE DRUG SUPPLIES TO THE UNITS. A PREVENTIVE EYE CARE DISPLAY WAS DEVELOPED AND USED IN AGRICULTURAL SHOWS THROUGHOUT KENYA. PLANS ARE UNDERWAY FOR A MAJOR SYMPOSIUM IN NAIROBI FOR ALL CLINICAL OFFICERS TRAINED IN OPHTHALMICS. THE IEF RECEIVED APPROVAL FROM THE OFFICE OF THE PRESIDENT TO SURVEY THE OCULAR AND NUTRITIONAL STATUS OF RURAL KENYANS. THUS FAR, SURVEYS HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED IN NYERI DISTRICT, CENTRAL PROVINCE AND KWALE DISTRICT, COAST PROVINCE. THE BRITISH JOURNAL OF OPHTHALMOLOGY IS EXPECTED TO PUBLISH THE RESULTS OF A PILOT SURVEY OF THE SAMBURU DISTRICT, RIFT VALLEY PROVINCES. ALSO, IT IS LIKELY THAT THE 5 SURVEYS CONDUCTED UNDER THIS GRANT WILL BE PUBLISHED BY THE BJO. DUE TO A POLITICAL DECISION BY THE MINISTRY OF HEALTH, KENYAN OPHTHALMOLOGISTS WILL NO LONGER RECEIVE TRAINING FROM THE IEF TEAM. A NEW EYE CARE MAGAZINE, "MACHO YA KENYA" (EYES OF KENYA), WILL BE DISTRIBUTED TO 20,000 RURAL SCHOOL CHILDREN. TWO SHOWS ON EYE CARE WERE BROADCAST, AND RADIO SPOTS ARE PLANNED. THE RURAL BLINDNESS PREVENTION UNIT WILL PRESENT LECTURES AND SEMINARS ON BLINDNESS PREVENTION AND PRIMARY EYE CARE. DURING 1978, 2 LECTURE SERIES WERE GIVEN TO CLINICAL OFFICER STUDENTS AT THE NAKURU MEDICAL TRAINING CENTER. LOCAL EXPENDITURES FOR 1978 TOTALLED $116,107. PATIENTS EXAMINED AT THERAPEUTIC UNITS TOTALLED 100,473. THOUSANDS OF CHILDREN WERE EXAMINED AT SCHOOLS AND PRE-SCHOOLER CLINICS. THIS REPORT IS ATTACHED TO AN EVALUATION (PD-AAG-052-B1) OF THE IEF PROGRAM.

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT TO IMPROVE THE EFFICIENCY OF WATER USE BY FARMERS IN THE INDUS WATERSHED, PAKISTAN. EVALUATION COVERS THE PERIOD 1968 TO 1979 AND IS BASED ON MEETINGS WITH PERSONNEL FROM COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY (CSU), THE US CONTRACTOR, AND ONSITE VISITS. CSU WAS MANDATED TO PRODUCE INFORMATION (RESEARCH) AND EXPERTISE (TRAINED PERSONNEL) CONCERNING ON-FARM WATER MANAGEMENT IN ASIA. IMPORTANT RESEARCH AREAS INCLUDED WATERCOURSE AND FARM IRRIGATION LOSSES; SOCIO-ECONOMIC CONSTRAINTS TO WATERCOURSE DEVELOPMENT; WATER USER ASSOCIATION AND MODEL LAW ISSUES; THE RELATIONSHIPS AMONG CROPS, SOIL, WATER, SALINITY, AND FERTILITY; AND IMPROVED WATERCOURSE TECHNOLOGY. IN THE AREA OF TRAINING, PAKISTANI COLLABORATORS NOT ONLY PERFORMED THE RESEARCH PLANNED UNDER THE PROJECT, BUT ALSO IDENTIFIED PROBLEMS AND INITIATED PROBLEM-SOLVING RESEARCH. MANY HAVE SUBSEQUENTLY MOVED ON TO IMPORTANT POLICY-MAKING POSITIONS WITH THE GOVERNMENT. OVER 150 TECHNICAL REPORTS AND PUBLICATIONS AND A NUMBER OF ON-FARM WATER MANAGEMENT SEMINARS WERE ALSO FORTHCOMING. THE 1979 DECISION TO CURTAIL AID SUPPORT TO PAKISTAN EFFECTIVELY TERMINATED THE PROJECT JUST AS CSU WAS MOVING INTO THE EXTENSION PHASE. SEVERAL IMPORTANT LESSONS HAVE BEEN LEARNED, INCLUDING THE NEED FOR IN-COUNTRY HUMAN AND INSTITUTIONAL RESOURCES FOR RESEARCH; THE IMPORTANCE OF CENTRAL RESEARCH INITIATIVES TO RESOLVE GENERAL DEVELOPMENT CONSTRAINTS; THE ADVANTAGES OF MOVING INTO EXTENSION AND APPLICATION OF RESEARCH RESULTS AS SOON AS POSSIBLE; AND THE NEED TO CONDUCT RESEARCH UNDER FIELD CONDITIONS. IN SUMMARY, THE EVALUATORS FEEL THAT A MAJOR BREAKTHROUGH HAS BEEN MADE TOWARD IMPROVING THE EFFICIENCY AND EQUITY OF IRRIGATION WATER DISTRIBUTION UNDER LARGE CANAL SYSTEMS. IF THE POTENTIAL OF THIS ACCOMPLISHMENT IS TO BE REALIZED, EXCEPTIONAL COMMITMENT AND PERSISTANCE OF THE HOST COUNTRY AND ITS DONORS WILL BE NECESSARY. IN THIS VEIN, THE EVALUATORS RECOMMEND THAT USAID/INDIA SHOULD STRIVE TO COMPLETE THE WORK UNDERWAY ON THE ANALYSES AND DESIGN OF WATER USERS ASSOCIATIONS, AND THAT AID SHOULD RECONSIDER ITS DECISION TO ELIMINATE THE TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER SEMINAR PLANNED FOR PAKISTAN.

Abstract: EVALUATES, FOR THE PERIOD 2/28/73 TO 6/30/79, LOAN TO THE CENTRAL AMERICAN BANK FOR ECONOMIC INTEGRATION (CABEI) TO SUPPORT CABEI FINANCING OF THE CENTRAL AMERICAN REGIONAL HIGHWAY SYSTEM EXPANSION. NO METHODOLOGY IS INDICATED FOR THIS LOAN COMPLETION REPORT. THE ORIGINAL TERMINAL DISBURSEMENT DATE HAD TO BE EXTENDED TWO YEARS TO 6/79 DUE TO THE LOW EXECUTION CAPACITY OF SOME GOVERNMENTS IN REGARD TO THE DESIGN OF PLANS AND BIDDING DOCUMENTS; DELAYS IN CONTRACTING CONSULTANTS; SLOW CENTRAL AMERICAN CONGRESSIONAL APPROVAL OF LOAN CONTRACTS; THE 1976 GUATEMALA EARTHQUAKE; AND BAD WEATHER. ENGINEERS FROM ROCAP AND CABEI MONITORED THE SUB-PROJECTS, PERIODICALLY INSPECTING CONSTRUCTION SITES TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS. SUB-BORROWERS, HOWEVER, WERE RESPONSIBLE FOR EXECUTING THE SUB-PROJECTS AND ALSO SELECTED CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTORS WITH THE APPROVAL OF ROCAP AND CABEI. CABEI PERFORMED WILL IN IMPLEMENTING LOAN AND OBSERVED ALL CONDITIONS AND COVENANTS. THE TOTAL PROGRAM COST WAS $39.5 MILLION, OF WHICH THE AID LOAN FINANCED $25 MILLION. FIVE HIGHWAYS, WITH A TOTAL LENGTH OF 273 KILOMETERS, WERE CONSTRUCTED IN HONDURAS (2), GUATEMALA, EL SALVADOR, NICARAGUA, AND COSTA RICA. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE LOAN AGREEMENT, THE ORIGINAL ILLUSTRATIVE LIST OF SIX PROJECTS SELECTED FOR LOAN FINANCING WAS REVISED THREE TIMES TO COPE WITH MORE URGENT HIGHWAY NEEDS. ALL PROJECTS OR SEGMENTS OF PROJECTS WERE RECOMMENDED ORIGINALLY IN THE CENTRAL AMERICAN TRANSPORTATION STUDY 1964-65, EXCEPT FOR GUATEMALA EARTHQUAKE RECONSTRUCTION. THE ONLY IMPLEMENTATION PROBLEM OCCURRED IN NICARAGUA, WHERE THE SUPERVISORY FIRM DID NOT ACCEPT PART OF THE WORK BECAUSE IT WAS NOT PERFORMED ACCORDING TO THE CONTRACTOR'S SPECIFICATIONS. WHEN THE ROAD WAS COMPLETED, THE DISPUTED PORTION REMAINED UNPAID AND LEGAL ACTION BETWEEN GON AND THE CONTRACTORS CONTINUES. THE PROJECT IS NOW COMPLETE. NO SPECIFIC MONITORING ACTIONS ARE RECOMMENDED IN REGARD TO POST-DISBURSEMENT COVENANTS. ROCAP WILL OVERSEE THE COLLECTION OF AMORTIZATION AND INTEREST PAYMENTS.

Abstract: EVALUATES AID PORTION OF A MULTI-DONOR PROJECT TO INCREASE THE QUALITY AND QUANTITY OF LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION IN KENYA FROM PROJECT START IN 4/74 TO 8/79. EVALUATION INCLUDED A REVIEW OF PROJECT AND OTHER DOCUMENTS, INTERVIEWS WITH APPROPRIATE GOVERNMENT OF KENYA OFFICIALS, DISCUSSIONS WITH AID, IBRD, AND OTHER INTERNATIONAL FUNDING AGENCIES, AND VISITS TO PRJECT SITES. ALTHOUGH SOME PROJECT ACHIEVEMENTS WERE OUTSTANDING, THEY OFTEN FELL SHORT OF UNREALISTIC PROJECT GOALS. ESPECIALLY DISCONCERTING WERE THE TOO SHORT TIME-FRAME ALLOWED FOR GOALS TO BE REACHED AND THE ABSENCE OF CONTINGENCY PROVISIONS IN THE EVENT OF A DROUGHT. CONCERNING SPECIFIC OUTPUTS, THE TRAINING OF KENYANS IN RANGE/RANCH PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT, THE IMPROVEMENT OF KENYAN RANGE MANAGEMENT TRAINING INSTITUTIONS, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF RANCHES ALL SEEMED TO BE GOING WELL. PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF GRAZING BLOCKS, BUT THIS HAS BEEN MARRED BY LACK OF MAINTENANCE. MANY OF THE CONSTRUCTED RESERVOIRS WERE RAPIDLY FILLING IN WITH SILT, AND ONLY ONE OF THE 37 BOREHOLES WAS OPERATING. THE PLANNED MEAT PROCESSING STUDY WAS COMPLETED IN 3/77, BUT FIVE OF THE SEVEN MAJOR RECOMMENDATIONS HAVE NOT YET BEEN ACTED UPON BY THE GOVERNMENT. THE CREDIT INSTITUTIONS ESTABLISHED TO ASSIST RANCH DEVELOPMENT WERE PRESSING RANCHES TO GET FURTHER INTO DEBT THAN WAS IN THEIR BEST INTERESTS. FINALLY, THE ESTABLISHMENT OF SERVICE AND MAINTENANCE FACILITIES FOR PROJECT EQUIPMENT HAS NOT BEEN ACHIEVED. AMONG THE UNPLANNED POSITIVE PROJECT CONSEQUENCES WERE THE SENSITIVIZATION OF TECHNICIANS, FINANCIERS, PLANNERS, AND INTERNATIONAL DONORS TO THE REALITIES OF A FRAGILE ENVIRONMENT AND THE REDUCTION OF FRICTION BETWEEN TRIBAL CLANS. SOME 39 RECOMMENDATIONS WERE MADE CONCERNING GENERAL PROJECT DESIGN AND STRATEGY; ECONOMIC, ECOLOGICAL, AND SOCIOLOGICAL CONSIDERATIONS; AND PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION, INCLUDING THE INTERESTING CONCLUSION THAT, ALTHOUGH THE EXPANSION OF CATTLE PRODUCTION OVER THE SHORT-RUN SHOULD BE FOSTERED BY PERMITTING CATTLE PRICES TO RISE, IT IS NOT IN THE LONG-TERM INTEREST OF THE PEOPLE OF KENYA TO INCREASE PRESENT LIVESTOCK NUMBERS.

Abstract: Evaluates project to improve animal husbandry, animal health, and range management in Ranching Association Area's (RAA's) in Tanzania's Masai District.  Evaluation covers the period 1969-10/79 and is based on document review, site visits, and interviews with project personnel and beneficiaries. During the period 1969-76, of seven projected outputs, only improved water availability met with more than very limited success; even this component experienced problems with equipment failure, faulty construction, and lack of fuel.  Little progress was made in range management, animal health, or other livestock targets:  plans were left unimplemented, the mortality rate of imported bulls was high, repair needs left animal dips inoperable, and lack of adequate equipment left disease control centers nonfunctional.  Moreover, after a promising first year, the Government of Tanzania (GOT) lost interest in the RAA's and in related marketing and extension efforts, dooming these components to failure. During the period 1976-79 (following a major project revision), achievements were strongest in the areas of disease control and participant training.  Even here, however, animal dip breakdowns, lack of supplies, and the failure of the GOT to assign returned participants to the Masai project reduced potential benefits greatly.  Although sketchy range management plans have been drawn up, and one rural training center established, both of these efforts have been plagued by serious organizational problems and implementation failures.  Plans for registration of and adequate water coverage for 40 villages and for short livestock and range management courses have either been suspended or are being implemented only haphazardly.  Targeted outputs regarding development of baseline data  and 40 miles of market access roads were a failure.  Overall, additional watering points and control of tick-borne diesases have been the components most valued by the Masai and represent the project's greatest contribution to increased livestock production and improved range care. Some 50 recommendations were made, among them that future projects: be limited in scope; include Masai input during the planning stage; collect baseline data; define priority project activities; and develop an indigenous capacity to maintain equipment and facilities provided under this project.

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT IN ZAIRE TO IMPROVE SMALL FARMER PRODUCTION AND INCOME THROUGH A REPLICABLE RURAL DEVELOPMENT PROCESS. EVALUATION, WHICH COVERS THE PERIOD FROM PROJECT INCEPTION IN 1976 TO MID 1979, WAS PERFORMED BY A CONTRACTED TEAM THROUGH INTERVIEWS WITH GOZ AND USAID PROJECT OFFICIALS AND SMALL FARMERS. PROJECT COMPONENTS, ESPECIALLY IN COMMUNICATIONS AND INFORMATION, ROAD REHABILITATION, AND MARKETING AND CREDIT, ARE NOT PERFORMING SUFFICIENTLY WELL TO ENSURE PROJECT SUCCESS. THE INTERMEDIATE TECHNOLOGY COMPONENT HAS BEEN THE MOST SUCCESSFUL, ESTABLISHING A WORKSHOP FOR FARM AND INTERMEDIATE TOOL PRODUCTION AND WIDE USAGE OF HAND MILLS. CROP TECHNOLOGIES ARE BEING INTRODUCED TO FARMERS (ALTHOUGH THE EXTENT OF THEIR USE CANNOT BE ASCERTAINED), AND 30 FARMER GROUPS, SKILL IN THE PRE-COOPERATIVE STAGE, AND 17 FARMER CENTERS HAVE BEEN ESTABLISHED. THE RESEARCH STATION AT NGABA IS BEHIND SCHEDULE. FARMER TRAINING WILL DEPEND ON ITS AVAILABILITY. TWO OVERALL ISSUES OF MAJOR CONCERN ARE THE QUESTIONABILITY OF EXCLUSIVE EMPHASIS ON MAIZE PRODUCTION AND WHETHER PROJECT ALLIANCES WITH THE POLITICAL AND ECONOMIC ELITE ARE ALIENATING SMALL FARMERS. A NUMBER OF DIFFICULTIES HAVE IMPEDED PROGRESS SIGNIFICANTLY. PROCUREMENT OF US EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLIES HAS BEEN SLOW AND LOCAL MATERIALS UNAVAILABLE. POLITICAL, SOCIAL, AND ECONOMIC INSTABILITY AND LACK OF A COHERENT GOZ NATIONAL RURAL DEVELOPMENT POLICY ARE AMONG SERIOUS EXTERNAL CONSTRAINTS. THE EVALUATION TEAM MAKES 29 RECOMMENDATIONS, INCLUDING THAT EXPATRIATE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE BE CONTRACTED FOR THE COMMUNICATION AND MARKETING COMPONENTS; A STEERING COMMITTEE BE ESTABLISHED TO COORDINATE GOZ POLICY WITH PROJECT OBJECTIVES; TRAINING FOR ZAIROISE PROJECT PERSONNEL BE CONDUCTED IN THE WEAKER PROJECT COMPONENTS NOTED ABOVE; A $500,000 REVOLVING CREDIT FUND BE ESTABLISHED TO PROVIDE SMALL FARMERS WITH PRODUCTION INCENTIVES; AND THAT ANOTHER IN-DEPTH EVALUATION OF THE PROJECT BE UNDERTAKEN WITHIN A YEAR. APPENDED ARE SEVERAL ANNEXES DETAILING ISSUES TREATED IN THE BODY OF THE REPORT.

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT IN NIGER, TO ATTRACT INVESTMENTS IN SMALL SCALE SURFACE WATER DEVELOPMENTS, BY PRODUCING TECHNICAL STUDIES FOR IRRIGATION SCHEMES. EVALUATION COVERS THE PERIOD FROM 8/76 TO 10/79 AND WAS CONDUCTED BY A CONTRACTOR ON THE BASIS OF ONSITE VISITS TO FIVE PROJECT AREAS AND INTERVIEWS WITH PROJECT PERSONNEL. A SURVEY OF SMALL MARSHY LAKES (MARES) WAS ACCOMPLISHED IN THE SAY ARRONDISSEMENT OF NIAMEY DEPARTMENT. THE STUDY, ALTHOUGH LACKING IN QUANTITATIVE STYLE, WAS USEFUL. A GOOD TECHNICAL DOSSIER EXISTS ONLY FOR THE KOULBOU MARE. A SURVEY AND HYDROLOGIC WORK ON THE TELOUESS KORI MARE, WHILE USEFUL, LACKS THE SOIL INFORMATION REQUIRED IN A TECHNICAL DOSSIER. DATA ACQUISITION AND CATALOGING NECESSARY FOR AVOIDING REPETITION AND GUIDING FUTURE PROJECTS WERE NOT ACCOMPLISHED. THE LIMINIMETRIC WORK DONE IN THE TAHOUN AND ZINDER DEPARTMENTS WAS UNACCOMPANIED BY ANY DATA ON DRAINAGE BASIN AREA, WELL YIELDS, OR QUANTITATIVE ESTIMATIONS. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDED TO GENIE RURAL BY PEACE CORPS VOLUNTEERS (PCV'S) WAS OF VARYING QUALITY. THE ORIGINAL PCV'S WERE POOR TECHNICIANS AND TWO OF THEM LEFT THE PROJECT PREMATURELY, CAUSING PROJECT DELAYS. LATER, FIVE PCV'S PERFORMED WELL IN CONDUCTING TOPOGRAPHIC SURVEYS. THE MAJOR IMPACT OF THE PROJECT WAS USAID'S OUTFITTING OF THE FIVE SURVEY TEAMS WITH  EQUIPMENT ADAPTED TO GENIE RURAL'S NEEDS. YET, GENIE RURAL DISPLAYED AN INDIFFERENT ATTITUDE THE PROJECT, PRESUMABLY BECAUSE THE PROJECT DID NOT MEET ITS NEEDS OF TECHNICAL SUPPORT AND BECAUSE IT LOST CONTROL OF THE PROJECT, WHICH BECAME A BURDEN TO ITS INFRASTRUCTURE. NONE OF THE TECHNICAL STUDIES FROM THIS PROJECT HAVE LED TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF SURFACE WATER PROJECTS. IN ANY CASE, THE NIGER GOVERNMENT'S NEED FOR SUCH STUDIES IS APPARENT. THE AVAILABILITY OF SKILLED MANPOWER IS ESSENTIAL IF THIS PROJECT IS TO ACCOMPLISH ITS GOALS.

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT, KNOWN AS THE INTERNATIONAL RICE RESEARCH INSTITUTE (IRRI) MECHANIZATION CONSEQUENCES PROJECT, TO SURVEY THE EFFECTS OF FARM MECHANIZATION ON SMALL RICE FARMS IN THE PHILIPPINES, INDONESIA, THAILAND, AND PAKISTAN; AND TO STRENGTHEN IN-COUNTRY RESEARCH CAPABILITIES. EVALUATION COVERS THE PERIOD 9/77 TO 9/79 AND IS A DRAFT REPORT BASED ON PROJECT STAFF INTERVIEWS, AN IRRI ISSUES LIST, AND ONSITE VISITS. SATISFACTORY PROGRESS WAS MADE TOWARD THE ACHIEVEMENT OF PROJECT PURPOSES. THE SURVEY SAMPLE WAS SELECTED AND THE QUESTIONNAIRE WAS DEVISED. METHODOLOGIES FOR DATA ANALYSIS WERE DETERMINED. SURVEYS WERE INITIATED IN THREE OF THE FOUR COUNTRIES, BUT DUE TO A LATE START, THE SURVEYS ARE BARELY UNDERWAY. PROJECT DESIGN WAS QUESTIONNABLE BOTH IN TERMS OF THE RELIABILITY OF DRAWING CONCLUSIONS FROM NARROW DATA, AND THE PROJECT'S UNDERESTIMATED TIME FRAME. PROJECT MANAGEMENT WAS UNSATISFACTORY DUE TO FREQUENT PERSONNEL CHANGES, LACK OF PROJECT DOCUMENTATION, AND POOR COMMUNICATION BETWEEN USAID AND IRRI. AN ASSESSMENT OF THE COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM IS NEEDED AS WELL AS SEMI-ANNUAL CONTRACTOR'S PROGRESS REPORTS. SEVERAL FACTORS CAUSES CONTRACT CHANGES. PROJECT FUNDING APPROVAL WAS DELAYED FOR ONE YEAR, CAUSING A DELAY IN DATA COLLECTION SINCE THE SURVEY, TAKEN OVER A YEARLY CROP CYCLE, HAD TO BE ADJUSTED TO A SUCCEEDING CROP YEAR CYCLE. PAKISTAN WAS NOT SURVEYED AND IRRI WAS UNABLE TO INITIATE WORK DUE TO EVENTS BEYOND THEIR CONTROL. DROUGHT AND OTHER UNFORESEEN EVENTS CAUSED THE NEED FOR CONTRACT EXTENSION FOR INTERVIEWING AND DEVELOPING QUANTITATIVE ANALYTICAL MODELS. ORIGINALLY, TWO SURVEY SITES IN EACH COUNTRY WERE TO BE SAMPLED. HOWEVER, IN THE PHILIPPINES AND THAILAND, THE TEAMS DECIDED TO SURVEY ONE SITE TWICE, RATHER THAN CHANGE SITES. THE EVALUATION TEAM APPROVED THIS ACTION. ADDITIONAL RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDE A REVISED TWO-YEAR EXTENSION CONTRACT WITH BUDGET CHANGES, AS WELL AS A MODIFICATION TO DELETE PAKISTAN, REALLOCATION OF ITS FUNDS FOR COST OVERRUNS IN THE REMAINING THREE COUNTRIES, AND INITIATION OF A SIMILAR PROJECT IN A FOURTH COUNTRY, SUCH AS BURMA.

Abstract: Evaluates project to increase the capability of selected Caribbean Development Finance Corps. (DFC) which finance economic development projects.  This special evaluation covers the period through 2/79 and is based on a contracted evaluator's visits to selected DFC's and inspection of their records. The author concluded that the weakness of the DFC's as loan guarantors and administrators was clearly demonstrated.  Two factors were held responsible:  the host government's perception of the DFC's role; and the DFC's perception of their clients. Regarding the first factor, most governments lacked agricultural and industrial development plans and subsequently regarded the DFC's as being a substitute, not a supplement for such planning.  Also, since DFC's generally have access to foreign funding sources, host governments attempted to gain control of these institutions in order to have access to their resources.  This action was taken by some governments without first establishing clear policy objectives.  DFC's, in essence, became the political and personnel instruments of host government leaders.  Since the DFC's dealt with foreign funds, the absence of a local financial stake in DFC operations facilitated the misuse of funds by the governments.  The officials responsible for administrating the funds had no compulsion to apply rigorous lending criteria to the projects. The author recommends that distinct policies and operational guidelines should be drawn up by the host governments, and that the cooperation of the latter in enforcing these giudelines must be secured. Operationally, the DFC's should recognize first, that applicants with the greatest probabilities of success are those with previous success at the technological level anticipated in the new project; and second, that new projects should be developed slowly so that the technical process can be absorbed by the participants.  The author notes that the DFC's may need assistance for loan appraisals, preferably from governments and international lenders.

Abstract: Evaluates project to assist the Government of Peru (GOP) in the development and reconstruction of areas damagedby a 5/31/70 earthquake and the floods of 2-3/72.  Evaluation covers the period from 6/8/72 to 4/1/79 and mentions no methodology. Project consisted of a loan to the Housing Bank of Peru (BVP), the primary implementing agency, to provide housing, utility services, and basic infrastructure to lower income families in the damaged areas.  The Organismo Regional para el Desarollo de la Zona Afectada (ORDEZA) implemented most of the earthquake area development, while the Ministry of Housing (MOH) directed the flood zone activities. Under this project, 13 self-help housing projects were constructed, providing shelter for 780 families.  The project's self-help technique was very successful. Three levels of housing acceptance emerged, based on beneficiary participation and reactions; 25% was highly acceptable, 38% moderately so, and 37% of low acceptance.  In Chimbote, 85,000 people will benefit from the constructed basic water, sewage, and electrical services, to be active in 6/79; an incomplete basic infrastructure delayed service operation. Electro-Peru successfully conducted major electrification projects in the Trujillo Pueblo Jovenes, establishing 22,816 connections; minor problems, however, extended the construction period by 18 months.  The MOH-constructed water and sewer services in the flood areas of Piura and Chiclayo, at a comparatively cheaper cost per connection, due to favorable site conditions, a lower water table, and better soil.  Other successes included the BVP's institutional growth in development financing and ORDEZA's increased ability to design and implement projects such as this one. Rivalries between participating GOP agencies caused substantial implementation problems.  ORDEZA, however, skillfully minimized such problems by continuing project construction regardless of any balking of other agencies.  Early problems in establishing project priorities and allocating funds slowed initial implementation.  Also, the unavailibity of water in Trujillo prevented construction of a water system there.

Abstract: Evaluates project to develop indigenous university-based extension services to serve small LDC industries. Evaluation covers the life of the project, 1/74-1/79, and is based on visits by the AID project manager and a private small industry expert to the Korean and Philippine subprojects and on a review of documents prepared by project universities, especially the final report of the Georgia Institute of Technology (GIT), "Stimulating the Growth of Small-Scale Industry." The funds provided by the AID counterpart grants to LDC universities were augmented by in-kind and monetary contributions by the respective host country agencies.  These joint resources provided for technical management assistance; appropriate technology; education and training; data collection, research, publications, and information exchange; organization linkages; and audiovisual documentation. The evaluators found that job opportunities were created through the project, although they rejected the document estimates, as these neither included indirect employment generated nor adequately accounted for factors external to the project which may have stimulated employment.  The progress reflected in most of the firms visited suggested that the assisted firms did improve their viability, but that the degree to which this can be attributed to project elements is uncertain.  Promotion of the extension service potentials among appropriate government agencies was found to be deficient in both countries visited.  Thirdly, although the project was apparently successful in introducing the counterpart universities to small firm extension functions, the level of funding did not allow the development of self-sufficient LDC extension capabilities.  Also, while some alternate methodologies for strengthening counterpart agencies were field tested, little analysis was provided in the program documents to adequately evaluate their success or failure. Finally, a long-term linkage is definitely necessary between counterpart institutions for the success of this type of program. This report is appended to the Project Evaluation Summary of 6/9/80 (PD-AAH-297-A1).

Abstract: Evaluates project implemented by the Community and Family Study Center (CFSC) of the University of Chicago to strengthen international population communication and training.  Evaluation, conducted at the University of Chicago by a special evaluation team, is based on review of project documents and interviews with CFSC staff and students, and covers the period 9/1/77 to 4/78. Major CFSC activities were two "action programs" in eight Latin American and two African countries, and short-term training workshops, including regional workshops in Kenya and Guatemala, and country workshops in Liberia, the Gambia, and Egypt.  CFSC also assisted communications departments of universities in Mexico, the Philippines, Bangladesh, and Egypt to develop competent faculties to teach family planning communication on a local or regional basis.  In addition, CFSC published family planning communication literature of various types, promoted close coordination among agencies engaged in population communication activities, and offered short-term and MA and PHD level academic programs. The main weakness of the program is the lack of a system of follow-on and evaluation.  To rectify this, it is recommended that CFSC monitor new activities for up to four years and develop procedures for gathering feedback from participants who have returned home.  A total of 31 other recommendations are made.  Included among these are that:  (1) concentrated attention be given to no more than four countries a year; (2) that French and Spanish-speaking technicians be added to CFSC staff in view of the workshops in Latin America and Africa envisioned in the five-year plan; (3) that the present AID policy of not encouraging study for PHD degrees be reviewed; (4) that CFSC determine the causes of the scant use made of project-generated information; (5) that training manuals written for the level of the target population be translated as the need arises; (6) that AID and CFSC confer on alternative ways of promoting advanced training of family planning information personnel; and (7) that qualified and experienced personnel be added to CRSC's full-time staff.

Abstract: Evaluates subproject to construct 105 kms of coffee roads in Haiti as part of a project to increase the productivity of small coffee farmers. This special evaluation, prepared by Group Seven Associates, covers the period 7/30/74 to 8/31/79 and is based on a review of project documents and reference works, interviews with project personnel, field trips, and a sample survey of locals involved in the project.  Government of Haiti (GOH) support has been far less than anticipated, but with no adverse results. Major departures from project design -- which seems to have been physically and institutionally inappropriate for Haiti -- were reversal of the planned roles for GOH engineers and the U.S. consultant (whose work was very effective), and the exceeding of road standards.  Haitian design standards generally exceed those of Kenya and Honduras for labor-intensive (LI) construction, the method used on all five project roads. Although only two kms of roads are completely finished, roads overall are 43% complete.  Notable construction features include placing a macadam cover of broken stone over a Telford base of 15 cm stones; applying a choker mixture to bind the macadam; and providing drainage facilities.  The cost to date has been $455,000, or 67% of the original budget.  Evaluators' projected costs for road completion, for which no further U.S. technical assistance is needed, are 3.3 times those projected by the U.S. consultant. The sample survey revealed that the project had positive socioeconomic effects. Evaluators present a research plan for collecting further such data for future road projects. Whether project responsibility should be shifted to the Department of Public Works depends on GOH commitment to road projects and to LI methods.  The latter commitment, plus the avilability of a sound rural development strategy and of adequate leadership and layout personnel, will also determine the use of LI methods in future projects in Haiti. Eighteen recommendations are presented, ten of them project-specific, the rest pertaining to LI methods in general.

Abstract: Evaluates project to institutionalize a nutrition planning process in Chile. This special evaluation, prepared by the contractor, the New Transcentury Foundation, covers the period from 5/78 to 9/79 and focuses on the performance of the Government of Chile (GOC) implementing agency, the Chilean National Commission for Food and Nutrition (CONPAN). The aggressive tactics of its early leaders established CONPAN's importance, but alienated many GOC agencies.  These leaders were removed and a GOC decree of 10/78 reduced CONPAN's national-level power, while leaving major opportunities for CONPAN to exercise influence at decentralized levels.  Its new leaders have adopted a more conciliatory approach to GOC agencies and a more realistic approach to nutrition planning. The 1979 implementation plan proposed to develop CONPAN's information and analysis capacity, as recommended in the last evaluation, by creating within CONPAN an analysis unit (still undeveloped after four years) and integrating it with CONPAN's existing information unit.  The plan also proposes a model regional nutrition planning project. Despite substantial staff changes, CONPAN has survived institutionally.  Its survival in the future, probably as a group of experts providing information and analysis to GOC agencies, will depend on whether CONPAN can:  (1) acquire a permanent staff dedicated to the basic tasks of analysis and planning (in contrast to past diversions into "projects"); (2) link its information and analysis units with GOC policy needs (instead of trying to analyze everything); (3) develop a methodology for the regional project, including training of participating GOC agencies; and (4) integrate projects within institutional goals. In order to further CONPAN's survival in line with the above, thirteen recommendations are made to USAID, including an immediate further extension of the loan's terminal disbursement date (already extended to 10/80) by at least a year. Evaluation is prefaced by a PES factsheet (PD-AAF-911-B1) which states that, due to other constraints, the loan will not be extended as recommended.

Abstract: Evaluates project implemented by the International Project Association for Voluntary Sterilization (IPAVS) to advance the acceptance of voluntary sterilization as a basic component of family planning and health service programs throughout the developing world. Evaluation covers the period 9/12/75-9/30/79, and included discussions with the IPAVS staff, country visits, and examination of records and reports. Evaluation team concluded that IPAVS has successfully met the objective of increasing the acceptance of voluntary sterilization.  In the future, however, program emphasis should be shifted from demonstration type projects to more widespread provision of voluntary steriliztion services (VS) -- especially to the hard-to-reach rural poor.  This objective will require:  (1) more emphasis on simple technologies, such as minilaparotomy and vasectomy as contrasted with high technology laparoscopic procedures; (2) utilization of auxiliary and paramedical health workers in a team approach; and (3) increased integration of VS into government health programs.  All surgical and nursing personnel in the IPAVS-funded clinics were judged competent to perform in their jobs. However, field visits revealed that many projects suffered from funding delays.  IPAVS should investigate alternative mechanisms for disbursing funds, including increasing the initial disbursement of funds, transmitting funds through USAID channels, direct mailing of checks to grantees, and (for the refunding of current projects) sending unsigned project documents to the grantee at the same time they are sent to Washington.  Vasectomy remains considerably underutilized and underpromoted. Experience has shown that information and education campaigns invariably increase the use of male sterilization services.  The evaluation team recommends that all new grants for sterilization services include a vasectomy component when possible.  The evaluators note that IPAVS is a responsible organization with the technical and managerial capacity to expand; and, in fact, could double its grant program with a modest increase in staff.

Abstract: Evaluates project to finance the construction of industrial estates in Antigua, Barbados, Belize, Dominica, Monteserrat, St. Kitts, and St. Lucia. This special evaluation covers the period up to 1/80 and was conducted on a country-by-country basis by survey teams. The Caribbean Development Bank (CDB) funded 11 sub-loans which contributed to the creation of 375,257 sq. ft. of factory space in the above countries. Presently, 26 firms are established within 345,257 sq. ft.  Of the total construction costs of $4.6 million, the CDB provided $4.2 million. Employment generation figures show that on the average, 172 sq. ft. per worker was attained.  This figure is considered low by international standards. In all countries, government support for industrial development projects has been evident, although incentives, while attracting local and regional investors, have lacked the outreach necessary for attracting multinational firms; and programs do not provide for worker assistance in new industries.  On-the-job training is the most effective means used by these governments.  Promotional and assistance functions within Barbados, Belize, and St. Lucia are both directed from either an international development corp., or a development finance corp.  In the other countries, these functions are divided.  The authors recommend consolidating these functions into one organization for better coordination. Concerning rental rates, subsidies should be eliminated and the rates increased.  Also, a uniform rental rate of $2.00 per sq. ft. for new and renewal leases and an annually revised rate review system should be instituted.  With the help of USAID experience, external promotional programs can be improved by establishing specific goals.  Project countries also lack the expertise for making demand projections regarding factory space.  USAID technical assistance in this area is essential and projections must be made for two-year periods beyond the planning of USAID and the CDB. Recommendations are also made for the CDB and USAID regarding inventory costs, building designs, and credit.

Abstract: Evaluates project to provide village level agricultural extension services in 33 provinces in Thailand.  This special evaluation covers the period 12/76-11/79 and is based on discussions with key personnel, on-site visits, review of project reports, and random surveys of project participants. As of 10/31/79, the training programs for the tambon agents, amphoe officers, subject matter specialists (SMS's), and trainers were implemented in 25 of the 33 provinces, a total of 8,540 weeks of training were provided, and all training had either been completed or scheduled for completion.  The program was closely adhered to, despite the late arrival of the consultants, its emphasis on theory rather than practical skills, and on quantity rather than quality and the lack of significant farmer-level training aids.  Recruitment and quality of extension personnel was only fair, however.  Shortages of SMS's and tambon agents impeded the provision of extension services to farmers. Routine interaction among farmers, extension personnel, and research scientists did not occur as planned, although efforts were made in this direction.  Final figures concerning an anticipated 50% increase in crop yields were not available. Spot readings, however, showed that harvest and income increased over 1977 and 1978. Recommendations were made to:  (1) expand the time allocated to SMS's for subdistrict and demonstration plot visits; (2) increase the number of SMS's at the local and regional levels; (3) extend the audiovisual consultant services by six months and the life of the project by one year; (4) provide training for all contact farmers; (5) emphasize both method and result demonstrations during training; (6) extend training to the remaining targeted provinces; (7) assign new staff to their home regions; (8) reexamine the tambon agent-to-farm family ratio; (9) expand the training time spent on field observations and practical exercises; (10) provide annual refresher training and training in personnel management and supervision; (11) conduct a pilot trial of the video tape recorder; and (12) review the validity and utility of the crop modules.

Abstract: Evaluates project to develop a community-based integrated rural development program (CBIRD) undertaken by Save the Children Foundation (SCF) in Aceh, Indonesia.  Evaluation covers the period 1976-1979 and is based on a field visit and a review of project reports and documentation. To date, CBIRD efforts have been concentrated in Tangse, a large subdistrict of 26 villages.  When it became apparent that the primary vehicles for organizing the rural poor, the community development committee (CDC), were being dominated by traditional leadership elements, two major changes were made to increase the participation of the poor:  (1) expansion of management training to include the poor involved in working groups; and (2) the formation of village-level development committees (VCDC's), each including, for the first time, a representative from the poorest element of society.  The VCDC's assumed greater operational authority, and the role of the CDC's changed from decision-maker to coordinator.  Funding was dispersed among all participating villages to reverse the concentration of efforts in a few areas.  By mid-1979, VCDC's were operating in each of the 15 villages in which CBIRD was functioning.  There has also been a shift in emphasis from long-term projects to those immediately impacting on the poor. SCF's open approach to management has maximized communication, especially with villagers.  SCF has also fostered informal relationships with both villagers and Government officials.  The latter have responded by greater support and cooperation for the CBIRD program.  These developments have been possible because of the small size and the relative isolation of Aceh. Although the project has been a success, SCF should face seriously now the problem of program coordination after it leaves, particularly since dynamic management appears to be the key to replicability. Also needed in the log run will be cost-benefit analyses of the 44 currently ongoing projects.
